The food is Southern Mexican, which means it has a more subtle spice, very flavorful, and isn't overloaded with cheese.  (Yay!)  Guacamole is delicious.  There isn't a lot I can eat (I'm a lactose intolerant pescatarian) and they took my favourite dish off the menu (the pescado veracruzano... it was truly amazing), but I go for experience.  I usually get the shrimp or fish tacos, which are great.  Sometimes I get the tilapia wrapped in a banana leaf, but it's a little pricey.   Great restaurant for small groups.  I would come more often, but their menu hasn't changed much over the last 5 years and I wish it would.  Barrio has received well-deserved lavish praise for years and now it kind of feels like it's just coasting.  Definitely worth trying.
I've eaten at both the downtown and airport venues. If you like Mexican food you'll love this place. If you don't like Mexican food, you will after you eat here.

good food. Guac was great. service was friendly. will go back but likely won't get the chicken mole dish again, as chicken was a little over cooked. Fish platter type dish was great though. Had lobster appetizer that was great. parking was easier than I thought. Got there early, around 430 or 5 on a sunday so it wasn't crowded, but got that way by the time we left. Churro dessert was to die for and would go back for JUST that.

This place has OK food but really bad customer service.  I got the fish tacos they where all right.  The waiter was rude when he asked if we wanted the check he said ill bring that and a police officer too.  I asked what he meant by that he was is just a joke.  Not a very good joke to me.  Oh and they add a 15 dollar gratuity tip when they dont even deserve it.

This is hands down my favorite Mexican restaurant in Phoenix arguably one of my favorite spots overall. The house made pomegranate guacamole is a must order every time. I love the enchilada's suizas but have tried several dishes all are fabulous. They have a great tequila selection and their margaritas are so fresh and delicious. Don't be discouraged by the location or the building itself (it isn't located in the best part of town) the staff is great and the food makes it worth the trip every time.

If I could describe Barrio Cafe in one word it would be OVERPRICED. I told the bartender I wanted a margarita but not too sweet and he suggested the lowrider. The margarita was expensive but it was strong and one of the best I have ever had. It didn't bug me that they served bread and tapenade instead of chips and salsa. I found the change refreshing and the tapenade was delish! We ordered guacamole while we decided what we wanted to eat. I didn't like the pomegranates in the guacamole and I had to salt it up a bit. We also ordered some fundido dip that was almost cold when we dipped into it. We asked for them to reheat it and I noticed they guy sitting next to us sent back his seafood dish for the same reason.....wasn't cooked well enough. You shouldn't be having these problems when you are paying an arm and a leg for your meal. I ordered the surf and turf for $46 dollars. It came with filet mignon topped with chorizo and goat cheese on top of mashed potatoes and a lobster tail. It was good but they undercooked my steak and the lobster tail didn't taste like it was as fresh as the waiter described. He said they fly in the seafood fresh daily. Even though the food is really good it is way overpriced. I would rather eat at Gallo Blanco for half the price.

The first time I went here, I LOVED IT! This time.... not so much.  We had awful awful awful service. Our server was slow, forgetful, and snotty.  YUCK.  I like the pomegranate seeds in the guacamole. I ordered the enchiladas suizas, and I found them to be oddly sweet and the chicken was chewy and tough inside.  I think this place has outlived it's useful lifespan.

Finally, I have had the chance to try this place! After seeing it on Guy Fieri's show, the boyfriend and I decided to check it out for NYE.   Not a fan of the neighborhood. However it looks like they are expanding to the building next door, and the exterior is very welcoming. On this particular night they were packed, but had a live (small) band jammed into the front.  Now, the food. Oh my god it was good. I Had the Pollo Poblano and highly HIGHLY reckons getting that. It's got this delicious goat cheese/cream cheese/ sour cream mixture of amazing on top of poblano peppers and juicy chicken. With a cream sauce and pine nuts, I was done.   My boyfriend had the famous pork. (Cochinita pibil?) it was amazing as well, he cleared his entire plate. Super tender and juicy. Yummmmmmmmm.    We had the guac as well, since it was rated best in Phoenix, however I didn't think it was the absolute best I'd ever had. Our waiter was pretty rushed as well so there were big chunks of guacamole too. Meh.    Otherwise, it's a must to go here. We will definitely be back when our leftovers are gone!
The service is good, the food is unique and it's close to my job for lunch. I take all my clients there and they always want to go back. For being in the ghetto the Barrio Cafe is great..... Thanks!

What can I say.....probably the BEST Mexican food I have had in years ! I had the Enchilada Suizas and it knocked my socks off. The first bite was heaven. The portion was just right and every forkful was a treat. The restaurant itself is mostly white with artist paintings hanging from the wall, but the outside is colorfully painted and a treat all by itself. The wait staff is great, friendly, cheerful and seem to be having a great time waiting/assisting the eager customers.  Looking around at what the other patrons were having made one want to stay and try a great number of dishes, everything looked like you wanted to go over and say, "Excuse me, can I have a bite of that ?". And there was no waiting for food, although the place as about 3/4 full, the order arrived within 10 minutes, barely enough time to sip a Margarita. So, as you can tell, I loved the place, and will return.

Everything great you have heard about this restauraunt is true. From the food and drinks to the service, it is all amazing. I have had quite a few things on the menu and it has all been outstanding. Get the guac! Seriously, get the guac.

Came here for a second time and got the shrimp quesadillas instead of the tacos, which I regret -- I stupidly didn't translate the description, and didn't realize how much goat cheese there'd be. Still liked it, but I liked the tacos a lot more.  The guac was still incredible. Keeping my rating the same.

I just have to say that I've been here three times since my first post and I can comfortably say that this is my favorite restaurant in Phoenix.   Guac, margs, and aesthetic...top notch when compared to the rest of what the city has to offer.   (but I am always up for suggestions on places that could rival my love for Barrio!)
Super whoa! Freaking love this place. I live in Mexico and Barrio is the real deal. Love their cocktails also. Yummmmmmmm!

I saw this place on The Food Network's Diners Driveins and Dives and it looked so amazing I had to put it on the list for my next Phoenix trip, and I wasn't disappointed. The host, Guy, seemed pretty smitten with this place, and I can't say I blame him.  The outside of the restaurant is covered with awesome graffiti style art, literary on all sides. The inside has a hip vibe to it and is broken into several small rooms with tables. We were seated right away on Saturday at lunch over a holiday weekend. Our server was with us quickly and was very nice and accommodating. He had no problem pointing out the couple things on the menu I should avoid, to stay away from da glutzen, but mostly everything else was gluten free.   We ordered the guacamole which was amazing and the unexpected pomegranate seeds added a nice sweet yet tangy component. I had seen a couple of their especialidades de casa featured on the show and it was the tilapia that made me decide that this place needed to make the top of my nom list. The Mojarra San Augustin was amazing. A piece of seasoned tilapia on a bed of the family recipe achiote and wrapped in a banana leaf. It was perfect. My friend had the spinach salad with pecans and golden raisins. She loved the spicy yet sweet dressing but wished she'd had more options as a vegetarian. I'm not sure what my other friends ordered, they are regulars here and love it.  Overall, wish I was still in the Phoenix area so I could explore this menu more. It has a great atmosphere, food quality is excellent, price is reasonable and service was good. Definitely recommend trying it out, Guy wouldn't steer ya wrong.

I am giving this restaurant four stars as it is the first time I've been there and until I go a second time I can't give it a five. My wife and I went here for lunch. Service was above par. They were attentive, kind and knowledgeable. The food was very good and packed with flavor. We had the suisa and we split a carne taco plate. Both dishes were very tasty. The prices match the quality of the food. That being said it is pricier for lunch. We spent $40 for two of us for lunch and did not have sodas or dessert.  In the not as great side of the table, I was looking for standard chips and salsa but they do not provide that like most Mexican restaurants.  Instead the offer bread and olives.  This was my least favorite part of the meal.   Final word, this is a very good restaurant. Its good for business lunches and dinners. I am excited to go back soon and give it a fifth star.

I been trying to get a table at this restaurant forever, but finally my wife and I had a chance today for lunch. Well we started with the guacamole and let me tell it was fresh well balance definitely one of the best guacamole I ever had, the pomegranate is the extra wow factor!! For entree my wife had the mole enchiladas it was good but we had better she tried both mole red and black but it wasn't the best one, I had the chile en ahogada that entree was really good every bit was enjoyable but it had a bit too much creamy sauce but you don't have to eat it its around the chile. Service was good and friendly. Even though I been waiting forever to go to this restaurant I wasn't that impressed

Five stars for the chef, The bartender, five more. And five for the mezuzah hanging next to the door.  No, I'm not Jewish But know of their ways. So as long as I'm here I'm out of harm's way.  So I drink your tequila all one hundred brands till you ask me to leave then mezuzah be damned.  I'm now in harm's way No mezuzah, unsafe. And what of St. Christopher who hangs from my neck? Well where was he only moments ago when I stood up too fast  and back down I did go?  So they pack up my pork and my chips and my bread to send me off packing where soon I'll find dread from tequila and pork, and guacamole with berries. And from this girl at the bar who I now know is married.  Barrio, I dedicate this plagiarized passage to your 120 brands of tequila.  Tequila, scorpion honey, harsh dew of the doglands, essence of Aztec, crema de cacti; tequila, oily and thermal like the sun in solution; tequila, liquid geometry of passion; Tequila, the buzzard god who copulates in mid-air with the ascending souls of dying virgins; tequila, firebug in the house of good taste; O tequila, savage water of sorcery, what confusion and mischief your sly, rebellious drops do generate! Without doubt, it was the tequila that made Bernard impatient, that befuddled him into mistaking the UFO conference for the Geo-Therapy Care Fest."  Oh please let me in I promise to be good. Not tell dirty jokes Or make fun of your hood As I sit at the bar  and play nice, oh I will. Eating all of my food as I lay off the swill.  WIth love.

Barrio Cafe has been around for quite a while now, and has a truly unique cuisine. I first found out about it because they hired me as a musician, years ago! The last time I was there was several months back. It's Mexican food, but not chimichangas and burritos, more like moles and nice sit-down food with traditional flavors and authentic combinations. I feel like I'm in a different country at the Barrio; it's exotic and not cookie cutter in the least. Very cool place.

We went on a very busy Friday night.  Crazy busy, but a fun atmosphere, "real" people, and great energy.  We have an excellent margarita while waiting.  There's a local band playing music- and they are very good.  We are seated after about 35 minutes.  We are under speaker so the music is so loud we can't talk.  Service staff is very friendly and professional, but also very busy.  Excellent bread and olive dip is delivered.    We order pork tacos and Pollo Poblano dinners.  Our food is prepared well.  Quality is excellent.  But our water glasses are empty for far too long, too often.  It was loud to a fault- likely a combo of acoustics, voices and speaker location.  I like me my loud music, but not so loud that I can't have a conversation at dinner.  The patrons as a whole appeared to be enjoying themselves.  There is a broad cross-section of people, variety of ages, ethnicities, friends, couples, groups, etc.  I enjoy a diverse crowd, and everyone was good-natured, which adds to the charm of this small and very busy restaurant.  Parking is tight but i've never experienced any damage in the back.     I've been a couple times before, and consistently experience a 4 or 5 rating experience.  This is the first time I've reviewed, and wish I could give a 5-star, but no-go.    Yes I will return, but not during one of the busiest times of the week.  No reservations, so be prepared to wait.

Barrio Cafe serves up nontraditional Mexican.  Okay. So some have complained this place does not offer traditional Mexican food. If you are looking for Taco Bell or Del Taco style fixings consider going elsewhere. But if you're looking for a cool and new twist on Mexican flavors this could be your spot.  The service here was quick and attentive. The busboy was fast to bring a basket of bread and an amazing olive spread (pictured.)  The flavors of the spread were pungent enough to be memorable yet not overpowering.  A side salad (pictured) was included with my lunch. It had a flavorful mixture of Roquefort cheese, dried cranberries, spinach and salsa. It would have been perfection had it not been for the too-spicy balsamic vinaigrette dressing which nearly disguised all the other flavors.  The Torta de Filetito (pictured) was my entree. The first decision I had to make was how to tackle it. It was piled too high to eat as a sandwich, yet trying to slice through the crusty bread (even with a steak knife) proved to be nearly impossible.  The fillet mignon was flavorful, though could have been a bit more tender. It was also to have included chorizo though I found no sign anywhere...or could it have simply had no flavor and been mistaken for the chipotle wine sauce???  The portion size was more than ample though many pictures of the same entree on yelp.com display this entrée with french fries. I did not see french fries on the menu nor were they presented on the plate. Could this have been what the restaurant considers a "lunch portion" or was it nearly forgotten?  A few tweaks and this place could be a five-star restaurant, in my opinion. I realize that space is at a premium though I personally do not care for the unisex restrooms. (One of the two was out of order, but this is the norm here anyway.). I may try this place a second time someday and if I do I think I'd like to try their margaritas.

Disappointed.  My friend's main course was cold which caused the mole to look like solid chocolate with white chocolate drizzle.   The inside was cold as well and since it was her first time she assumed this was correct.  She didn't want to cause a fuss, but requested we not come back again.  My halibut was cooked, but flavorless as was the rest of the shrimp.  The flavors hadn't been infused as would have occurred if marinated.  My dish was lukewarm and I knew I wouldn't come back.

Heard great things about this place so I was excited to take my family today to try it out. First, our waiter, Cesar, wasn't too friendly and had attitude when we were asking questions about the menu. We were surprised to get bread and diced olives instead of the typical chips and salsa. When our drinks came out, we were disappointed in seeing the size of them. You pay $5 for a soda and expect larger sizes and free refills. My niece ordered juice and got the wrong one so we had to ask the waiter to replace it. We were hungry and waited nearly an hour for our food. Then, when our dishes came out they weren't what we asked for. We ordered the chilaquiles with scrambled eggs but they were sunny-side up when the dishes were brought to our table. Portions weren't too bad but expected more for the prices, no beans and rice! My niece and nephew ordered the chicken enchiladas but they had very little cheese on them. The kids left most of their food as it was mainly tortillas covered in sauce with a few pieces of chicken. As if that wasn't bad enough, for 3 adults, 2 children and 4 month infant we were charged a 20% gratuity. Needless to say our experience was not worth the $115 we paid. Never going back again! Save your money!!

Good food. 3.5 out of 5 but i'm nicer than most people think so i give it a four.  guacamole was nice, the pomegranate in it was a great gesture but felt it a bit having sat too long before being served.  The "pollo" was reasonable but the "mole" was amazing.  their house made drinks way too sweet.  service: friendly and a bit brusque ...the server almost snapped at me saying "i don't understand you!" i should have told him because he was a damn idiot but decided to take the high road.  anyways at the end all worked out and i would enjoy going back there on my next visit.  Thanks to my good friend Erin for her recommendation.

Came for dinner last night....Aaron was our waiter...I felt the quality of the Food and the temperature has seriously deteriorated. The morale of the bartender seemed very "flat", however the courtesy "smiles" of the waiter  Did not make up for the fact that we felt "rushed" throughout the meal, even Ordered takeout because we loved the food so much In the past! the ... Most disappointing part, was that the waiter forgot to bring the "chile nogada" to the table which I Ordered as a part of the meal...and his response Was "oops sorry my mistake I'll put in now....wow, it was brought to us at The end of our meal.....this would not be acceptable in the "Windy City."   the food in general was served "lukewarm, they seemed short staffed and  Definitely a moral issue.....Cesar was not even smiling?.... What is going on guys....You have a great thing here....you are going to lose it....  the reviews are not impressive and the quality of,service and food is clearly Deteriorating...".The ambience is noisy, true but it is small quarters to,be expected....for the price of the food ....you should be on your game!!!! by the thick cut Zucchini has to go....it is economical, but the customers Are saying very boring and I clearly understand that....There is EQ out there From customers...read the meaning.......
Delicious mole chicken amd one of the best margaritas in town. Dont miss this charming authentic place.

Great restaurant but if the crowds are too much then I'd drive up the street to Asi es la Vida.  The gauc, cochinita pibil, and churros con cajeta is the ideal trio for dinner.  The place is well done albeit very crowded and noisy.  The staff quality varies depending on who is waiting your table.
Upscale Mexican in a cool no frllls enviroment.  Tried and loved the Enchiladas chicken and seafood. Great sauce. Salads and veg with entrees. Good shit.
Love this place. I got the shrimp salad? (Can't remember what I got exactly...) The mango are really fresh. :)  A bit pricey though.

This place is good, I've been there a couple times...love the ambiance, the art in the walls. They have live music on Fridays! The guacamole was the best, almost better than mine, I love the pomegranate. Horchata in a coke bottle, and cochinito pibil tacos are delicious!

I like Mexican food and this place did not disappoint! My family and I were in Phoenix for only a few hours and my husband's cousin suggested coming here for dinner. The outside wall art was an added bonus. Best dinner suggestion ever! Although there was not a 'kid's menu' and hardly any food to choose from, we were able to get my daughter a few corn tortillas and chicken to make her own version. Problem solved. Our meals were fantastic and the sangria was the best I'd ever had!

See the guys in triple D and have been wanting to eat here done. I live in So Cal but come for business a fair amount so it's been tough to get here but I finally made it. Sooooooo glad I did.!! Cochinita Pibil was bar far the best I've had. I had them make me up a low rider marg to go alongside and it too was money!     All i can say is come here and enjoy a non greasy, non traditional ( no chips and salsa, no rice and frijoles) mexican good joint.  It rocks! !!!

Located on the west side of 16th St. between Osborn and Thomas Road in a tiny old strip mall in the heart of the 'hood, it's not called Barrio for nothing.  This has gone from great neighborhood find to being written up in the New York Times as a "must do" when in Phoenix, so be early or be prepared to wait.  The food and atmosphere def have a funky yet festive, artsy feel.  The food is along the similar vein of Padres; but featuring a guacamole appetizer that shouldn't be missed as it's mixed for you fresh at your table and served with big round chips ...yum!  Again with the desert ...some chocolate creation to die for!  Moderately priced.

Love the artwork and the fish tacos were good, too.  I'd like to try more of the menu because I'm not sure if I like the place as much as I think I do.  Well, that's confusing but it's not my fault because this restaurant obviously seduced me.    Okay, I can at least say that I'll be back because, if nothing else, the made-from-scratch horchata in a Coke bottle is very good.  (No credit to Coca-Cola here although, considering the ongoing slide in soda sales, the company might think of copying the Barrio Cafe's cheeky idea.)

Last month, I went to Barrio Café while visiting Phoenix.  I was excited to see Chef Silva's take on Mexican cuisine.  Surprisingly, it ended up being one of the most frustrating and negative restaurant experiences I've had in a couple of years.  While I was genuinely amazed by how wonderful some of dishes were that night, my partner and I received extremely poor table service, experienced long delays waiting for our entrees, and received cold food that had to be replaced.    My partner and I arrived on a pretty busy evening.  After getting on the wait list, I ordered a cocktail at the bar.  The bartender forgot my order, and then forgot what type of drink I ordered.  Once that was sorted out, we waited in the outside patio area enjoying more drinks until our table was ready.  At that point in time, the rush was over and tables were slowly starting to clear.  After being seated, we ordered the shrimp quesadillas and queso fundido as appetizers.  For dinner entrees, we ordered the duck breast and mole chicken breast. Our two appetizers arrived promptly.  The shrimp quesadilla was amazing. I am not sure what I was expecting, but I loved it - the reduction sauce had a lot of strong, fresh flavors and the shrimp was of excellent quality.  The queso fundido was also delicious. It was spicy but not overpowering, and the taste and texture of the cheese and crème mix was amazing.  All the flavors blended really well.    Over half an hour later, we realized we had still not gotten our entrees.  By then, our section of the restaurant had almost cleared out and there was no sign of our server.  We overheard the people at the remaining table in our section complaining they had received the final bill, but had not been served some of the food they had ordered. More time passed, and we were about to get up and find someone (anyone) when a new server came into the room with our entrees.   On my first bite of the duck, I noticed the skin was dried out and rubbery, and it was not warm. My partner took a bite of his mole chicken breast and then said to me "Is your food cold?"  We confirmed that the sides were cold too.  The grilled zucchini was barely room temperature, and the polenta-based side was actually cold in the center, as if it had been refrigerated but not properly reheated.  At that point, my partner immediately got up and found the server in the other room.  All he said was "our food is cold." The server didn't blink an eye, or act surprised. Rather, she rushed in and scooped up our plates while saying she'd get us replacements.  Although speculation, we wondered how long our food had been sitting out before the second server brought it to us, and if she had hoped we wouldn't notice anything wrong.    Eventually, our original server came back to our table and I think it was the first time we had our drinks refreshed since we had been seated.  We decided we were fine waiting for the new entrees and made polite chit-chat.  At that point, the restaurant was quiet, almost empty.  Silverware was being prepped, and linens were being placed on tables for the next day.    By the time our entrees arrived, over an hour had passed since we had ordered. Even though the original dishes came with polenta, it was now conspicuously missing from both plates.  We also noted there was a lot more zucchini.  The duck was fine, but nothing out of the ordinary.  The properly prepared mole sauce with my partner's dish, however, was really delicious. Spicy, and a lot of complex flavors that meshed together beautifully.  It went really well with the chicken, which had a smoked taste that complimented the sauce very well.  At that point, though, we just quietly finished our meals.    When finished, the original server said they'd like to comp our desserts if we were interested.   Nothing piqued our interest, but we ordered flan to share since one should never turn down a free dessert.  It tasted fine.  Overall, I see why people rave about the food, which made our experience there all the more frustrating.  While the entire staff was courteous, the service was completely substandard from the moment we were seated.  I strongly suspect they simply forgot about us and that our entrees sat out getting cold for quite some time before they realized their error.  They didn't try to correct it until we called them out.  They did not seem surprised when we did.  After all the delays and food problems, we got a comp'd a $10-ish dessert.  That's not experience you should get with a James Beard recognized restaurant and chef.  So that's why I gave it a one-star review.

I'm not a big yelper and usually only write reviews when something blows me away and this place did!  My wife and I were in Phoenix for a few days and lucky for us Barrio was not far from the hotel we were staying at (Embassy Suites).  This was such a great experience.  The food was amazing, service was great and the Micheladas were out of this world good!  Also, they had a couple guys playing some live music(if anyone else was there 04.04.15 please message me who they were, would like to buy/download some of their music if available).  Overall great restaurant and highly recommended!

Had a wonderful dinner last evening at Barrio Cafe with hubby and a friend from Seattle. We can all recommend the Guacamole, made fresh, table-side, and the "real" margarita's -- Tequila, agave nectar, lime juice -- none of that rancid "sweet and sour" stuff, thank heavens! I enjoyed the Tacos de Pescado (fish tacos), Bob had the Pescado del Mar (halibut w/a shrimp, scallop, lobster sauce), and Ron had the Cochinita Pibil (slow roasted pork). This ain't no Taco Bell, folks! Fantastic, fresh authentic Mexican food! We finished with a digestif (sipping tequila) Don Julio Añejo - YUM! I would give this place 5 stars, except there needs to be more appetizer and entree choices for those of us with soft shell seafood allergies -- Yes, I know everything can be made without certain ingredients -- but if you take off the shrimp or lobster or crab and are not prepared to make it differently, I feel a little "cheated" on the experience (not to mention, price).  And please, do NOT remove the choices you have now as my husband and friends LOVE them! ;)

I have been fortunate lately because most places that I've taken the time to eat at have been very good.  This place is no exception.  Great authentic Mexican food.  I had slow roasted pork tacos with incredible fries and chipotle ketchup.  Simple but great food.  The pork tacos were very tender and had just the right amount of spice.  My wife had an avocado, mango, shrimp, tomato salad with a vinegarette.  It was very tasty.  Again, simple and fresh.  This is the only place in the valley we've been where they can actually make a margarita correctly.  If you've ever been to Mexico they typically use quality tequila, fresh sqeezed lime juice, and and orange liquor (triple sec, cointreau).  The bartender here makes them just like that, no disgusting sweet and sour or other sweet juices.  You should be able to taste the tequila and just because there is tequila in the drink doesn't mean you're going to turn into a raging drunk and black out.  If you drink enough of anything that will happen.  A good 100% agave tequila adds flavor.  Try it you might like it.  He also gave us a great idea for making margarita's with tequila, lime, and a little agave syrup.  Cool guy and great idea.  You can buy agave syrup at trader joe's or fresh n easy.  We use 2 shots of tequila, 1 shot fresh lime juice, and 3/4 shot triple sec or cointreau.  However, instead of the triple sec or cointreau I am going to try 1 big teaspoon of the agave syrup.  Should be good.

Wonderful lunch! I had the Carne Asada tacos and they were delicious - small, double-shelled street tacos with Cotija cheese and pico de gallo. My husband had the Enchiladas Suiza and those were delicious as well. My mom had the Chile en Nogada but I am not sure how that was since she hate it so fast I didn't get a chance to try it! :) Wait staff was friendly and everything was delicious. The fryer was down today so I didn't get to try the churro rellenos but next time I am getting it for sure!
Great food. Who cares what it looks like outside. Fish tacos were amazing. Check this place out if you want authentic Mexican.
I dare you to find better Mexican food on the planet! Chef Silvana is a culinary genius and Barrio Cafe is, in my opinion, one of the top 5 restaurants in Phoenix.

This is a must try if you are in the neighborhood. It is not your typical Mexican restaurant, this has more of a Oaxacan cuisine than the usual Mexican fare.   To start off, they don't serve chips and salsa while you wait for your food, instead you get bread and Tapenade, totally awesome. I ordered Chilaquiles de Mole and it was the best I've ever had. The portion was quite large as well.  The place is very small and they tried to squeeze in as many tables in there as possible which made the place too stuffy and too close to other people dining in; and I presume it could get too noisy as well. I got in here early so it wasn't too crowded, although it might not be a comfortable place for a cozy dinner on a Saturday night.

Provender: cochinita pibil tacos with salad. They also serve complimentary bread with a unique salsa. There are two dining areas. Staff was excellent, very attentive.  Prices: reasonable, taco combo and some Micheladas will run you about $20.  Parking: is parking behind the building near the rear entrance.  People: fun for all ages.  Perks: I like this place because of the artwork, both inside and out. This is a great place for a girls night out, not bros that are starvin' Marvin. I didn't find the tacos to be as flavorful as other spots I've been to in Phoenix, but maybe I came at a bad time.

We were told about this place before visiting Scottsdale and decided to go.  We were not disappointed.  The margaritas were terrific (a great selection), and the food was equally good.  It is one of the best restaurants I've been to.

I'm disappointed.  I  saw this place on a top 10 best in the country list. It's more French than mexican. When you sir down yoy get bread and something that looks like olive paste.  I loved the spread but the bread was slightly stale. But eatable.  I was in the more for chips so u got guac it said award winning. It was more of a avocado salad.  Are you staying to see a grand.  But I did like the guacamole it was different with cran raisins.  I ordered carne tacos because the chillrenno sauces scared me.  The meat was high end trays like a roast. Not like asada. The problem wad it was very beefy. I have to say it was gross I should have sent it back.  I know what your thinking beef is beefy. But this was bad. If you want new types of recipes and don't mind paying twenty dollars plate fire a dumpy place with white table clothes go try. There is a lot to like about this place

First time here, on the recommendation of other yelpers! I must say it was delicious!!! Big BOLD, spicy flavors :)   I ordered the Guacamole del Barrio to start, it didn't came with pomegranate seeds as seen in other yelp reviews. It came with dried cranberries. It was still fresh and had balanced flavor! I also ordered the Organica Margarita. It was very crisp and refreshing and a decent pour of tequila!   For lunch I decided on the Kuali de Camaron. I saw a gentleman at the table next to me with this order and I was sold on appearance alone. It had bold, spicy and VERY fresh flavors! Large enough to serve as a main dish for me. My guest ordered the Pollo Panlano. It was opposite, creamy and fresh taste, it was a large dish. It came with a side of the chipotle mash potatoes and grilled zuchinni. They did have a Sunday brunch menu until 3 and had a live musician until 2pm.   The restaurant is rather small and very busy, so they were a little slow with the service in the beginning until the servers caught up, but our server Jamie was very pleasant and apologized for the delay.   The artwork (murals) on the exterior walls were beautiful. And the artwork hanging inside was great too! Overall great atmosphere and amazing food! Can't wait to come back and try more!

I'll admit that my expectations for this place were probably higher than they should have been.  A James Beard Award winning chef serving food at reasonable prices?!? Who would've guessed it?  And I love mexican food, so this seemed like a win-win for me.  I'd been talking with my girlfriend about going to this restaurant since we moved to Phoenix.  To start off with, I love the character of the place.  So many restaurants in Phoenix/Scottsdale try way too hard with the modern trendy look, so its nice to have some character.  The drinks were good and reasonably priced.  The horchata texture was a little different (being grainier than I'm used to), but still good.  My girlfriend's margarita was pretty tasty, but nothing special.  I didn't try their guacamole which I regret, because when I saw them making it table-side it looked delicious.    Considering everything I heard about this place, I was a little disappointed when the food ended up just being pretty good.  I love a good mole sauce, and our server really talked it up.  Unfortunately, when the food arrived the mole sauce was okay and the chicken was dry.  My girlfriend's cochinita pibil was quite a bit tastier than my pollo en mole.  The portion sizes are large, and it'll definitely fill you up.  I'm willing to give this place another shot since you don't win a James Beard award for just decent food.  Next time I'll probably try the chilies en nogada since it's the "iconic dish", and just see if I didn't visit on an off night.

Just got back from Barrio Cafe a few minutes ago and I just have to say how much I loved it there before I fall into a deep food coma.  Guacamole. Absolutely adored this guacamole, because I love when there's, well was it pomegranite seeds or cranberries (?), whatever it was..it just makes the guac a little sweeter and gives it a different taste. It was served with really thick baked tortilla chips. We accompanied this guac with a yummy sangria and my hubby had a margarita.   Next, the Quesadilla Langosta Boraccha. This had garlic and tequila lobster on corn tortillas covered with Oaxacan cheese and another white cheese. The waitress couldn't be excited enough to have us try it, and I'm glad we ordered it because it was that good!  Cochinita pibil - the achiote seasoning really set this 12 hour  slow roasted pork off!  Enchilada del Mar - Oh-so-rich enchiladas with lobster, scallops and crab topped with queso de cabra!  Since we live so far, I decided to order the Flan de mi Mami and Churros Rellenos.  Yes, we could not help but order dessert too because we don't know our limits. Churros are perfect! The flan was thick, the right texture, consistency, and flavor (just like my best friend's mom from Guadalajara makes it)!   Since we came on a Sunday, they had a guitarist playing from noon until 2pm. He played all traditional classic songs on his Spanish guitar. It felt "just right" being there. I can see what all the hype is about! It is on the pricer side so go here if you want something extra flavorful and with a different edge.

The food is exotic and tasted ok , however it didn't come out well on the other end.  I spent over 140 dollars to get food poisoning from this overpriced restaurant that has such poor hygiene.  The bathroom was filthy which makes me wonder what could be lurking in the kitchen.  Bring your own sanitation napkins if you go here.  Where is the food inspector?

I am so in love with this place that words cannot do it justice. I've taken every out-of-town guest here, and they've all loved it. Tableside guacamole with pomegranate seeds: inspired. Seafood enchiladas: divine. You will probably have to wait, but it will be so worth it.

Tried Barrio cafe again. Still had the same experience. I actually ordered the same thing as last time- the thing I really wanted to try they no longer make- "FOREVER", I was told. So, anyhow- again, the mariscos enchiladas were killer. I did find a shell in my food again, but only 1 this time. My margarita was not very good- I tried a house one this time. It was just very sweet. My friend had one that was sort of a red color. It wasn't very good either. I don't think he finished it. He originally tried to order a different one, but the server told him not to- said it tasted like "cough syrup".  The food tastes good, the drinks just aren't great. It's very expensive. It was $13 for guacamole. They make it table side, but our server put in way too much lime juice, so it was... well, it was okay, but probably not $13 ok.   I don't know... $95 for 2 drinks, 1 guacamole and 2 entrees seems steep to me. I do like the place, but I think it will just be a once in awhile spot. I have had much less expensive meals at swankier places in the valley. It's not that swank is important- I just am weighing the value differences.  Our server discouraged my friend from many of his entree choices telling him certain things were not good... eek. I appreciate her honesty, but kinda a bad sign about the food.
This place is the best! The food is authentic with a nice flare. The service was fast and great. The portions are perfect and the drinks exceptional!

Central Phoenix. CenPho. Cennypoo. What am I going to do with you? Every time I think I can't possibly fall any harder for you, you surprise me with something new and unexpected that blows my mind. No, you don't have the stereotypically sexy look at first glance that Manhattan or San Francisco or Chicago do. To be honest I can barely remember our first date, which I think was when I stopped at Majerles in '98 before walking on to Bank One Ballpark to watch the fledgling Dbacks. Admit it, you weren't even trying to impress me back then, were you? I walked you back to my car hoping for a lil' somethin' after the game, but you barely even looked at me and I had nowhere to go. So back home I went, to that hot sexy young thing I was with at the time. What was her name? Oh yeah. Tempe. Wow. She was something. Back in the day, all the other cities would see me with her and glare with envy at how good she looked strutting her stuff on Mill Ave on a Friday night.   Slowly but surely, you began to wage your subtle campaign of charm on me. Even a jaded guy like me began to notice all the little things that really matter in life. I woke up one morning and there you were with a tray in hand and, on it, Matt's Big Breakfast. I'll never forget that other time when you tricked me into wandering up Central Ave and "accidentally" stumbling across Lux. Need I go on? It seems like every other time I'm with you, I make a new discovery. The more I get to know you, the more tiny bursts of elegance and grace and uniqueness shower my senses. No, not all of them are on one street tightly bunched together like those snooty runway models New York or San Francisco, which are so uppity that I'd have to be a multimillionaire to even have a chance to really enjoy them anyway, much less afford property. No, you make me dig a little deeper, look a little closer, and do a little exploring before I'm rewarded with your precious gems. A good seductress knows how to maintain an aura of mystery about her. And you, darling, are good.   So here I am, already having developed a pretty huge crush on you. And then you up the ante by another notch. Cafe Barrio. Barely visible, in a nondescript strip mall by 16th Street and Thomas. On a Wednesday night I walked past a crackhead through the run-down parking lot to enter through a backdoor, my suspicious mom in tow. And once again, you blow me away. The place is packed. I hear laughter, engaged conversation, people with grins on their faces, people on dates, another dude also with his mom (who actually smiled knowingly at my mom as we walked by). An entire world of urban happiness that's invisible to the commuters whizzing by outside on 16th street. What is this food? It's not traditional Sonoran, that's for sure. Ohhhh, I see: it's "modern Mexican with a heavy French influence," as your waitress put it. Sure. Find two of the kinds of cuisine I love most, and somehow find a way to combine them in one, all in an unpretentious setting 6 minutes away from my house. Damn, woman, you are good.   I don't say this lightly. When you came out with a tray, cut open that avocado, and mixed up various fresh ingredients in front of our very eyes to make the tastiest guacamole me or my mom have ever tasted in our life, I knew the moment had arrived. I'm ready to take the plunge. I'm ready to say that I don't want to ever live anywhere else, because there is no way I could get to know someone as intimately, as closely, as sweetly as I do you. Yeah yeah, there are other fish in the sea. I know that. But you're my fish, Cennypoo.

Saw the great reviews and had to check it out. Very authentic and creative Mexican food. The place has tons of character and is definitely a stand out. The service was outstanding, drinks were refreshing and everything we ordered was great. I would highly recommend trying it out.

We both agreed the queso fundido was the best queso dip ever!! It was an explosion of taste.  We ordered the fish of the day, alaskan halibut, veracruz style, and carne asada enchiladas suizas style.  I think the queso fundido killed the taste buds for everything else.  Everything else tasted a little bland but still have good flavor.  We probably should have eaten the queso dip last. :)  The horchata is so so.  it's a little too sweet.  service was so so.  bill for 2 before tip is $70.

My husband and I are from out of town; we had an early flight out of Phoenix, were in town for one night only and were looking for a place for dinner. The AAA guide sent us here; it did not disappoint. We had kind of a long wait, but we ordered drinks from the friendly bartender to pass the time. When we were finally seated, we promptly ordered the guac. It was fresh and delicious-the pomegranate seeds added a nice touch. I got the chicken enchiladas suizas, which were also great. Hubby got the grilled tacos; they were also fresh and tasty. I have no idea when I'll be in Phoenix again but if I ever am I'll go back!

Talk about cognitive dissonance!  I love the idea behind this place: authentic cuisine, art adorning the walls, innovative cuisine, no-frills attitude, and a James Beard nominated chef!  Here's what kills this place: Gabe. He is one of the worst servers I have had in a while. He killed the experience, made us want to leave in a hurry, and, in essence, ruined a nice dinner.    Details of the food/drinks: -Beers were $4.75. Hubby got the House Margarita and, while he did say they were poured weakly, it was quite refreshing and used a great mix. -Quesadilla with Langostine Borracho: My favorite dish of the evening.  It didn't arrive "quesdilla" style at all.  We had 4 small tortillas topped with the grilled langostine and wonderfully flavorful chunks of goat cheese; there was a flavorful pico de gallo in the center.  It was totally unexpected and totally good. -Cochinita Pibil: everyone raves about this dish.  It was very well prepared, with slow-roasted pork, freshly made tortillas, sour-orange onions, a wonderful mashed potatoes made with Chipotle peppers (which I found out from a food runner since Gabe was MIA), and an interesting vegetable to go with the asparagus. I think this vegetable is the Chayote, from listening to another waiter explain things to his guests with great enthusiasm (cue jealous looks now).  With all this, something didn't quite add up in the dish.  The flavors didn't come together and wow me. -Chicken Mole: The mole sauce was nice, with a good complexity, but there was hardly any sauce on the plate.  Nicely cooked pieces of chicken wrapped up in tortillas, with mole and a cream sauce drizzled over the top. More Chayote and Asparagus.  Good but not great.  Now onto Gabe.  Ooh! I'm still so mad!  He was gruff, inattentive, and just rude.  When I asked if they had pitchers of beer, I got a brusque "No," as he looked down his nose at me.  The hubby ordered his drink, and I said I'd like another minute.  That was a mistake. 5 minutes later he brings the hubby's margarita and doesn't ask if I'd like anything; he just walked away.  As we flagged his down to order our appetizer, I was finally allowed to order a glass of water and a beer.  We had to flag him down for everything. And when the option of dessert came up, he rattled them off to us, without explaining them and, when we weren't ready to decide yet, left again.  A wonderful young lady who boxed up our food brought us a menu so we could read about the desserts.  I was so mad that I didn't want to pay 12 bucks for a dessert and have to deal with Gabe any longer.  Overall final thoughts: -Innovative chef, with interesting ideas. Some cohesiveness is missing from some dishes though. -Fix Gabe. Seriously. He ruined our night! Other servers were warm, friendly, answered questions, checked on their guests, etc. -Prices are a bit steep. I'm not cheap by any means, but I felt like we paid a lot and didn't receive quite the same in return.   -Seriously about Gabe.

Ate at the Sky Harbor Airport location in Phoenix.  The cochinita pibil was good in the tacos, but it was overpriced.  Good food, but not outstanding and a little too expensive for me for the quality and quantity.

As did others we drove by the first time but the two room cafe lived up to its best Mexican restaurant rating for the past five years by the AZ Republic.  During the day the guacamole with olive oil, vinegar, onions, cilantro & pomegranate seeds is not made at the table and includes delicious (not calorie free) topopos (round, fried chip like tortillas). For a side salad we had an unusually tasty spinach salad with a hint of sweet & spicy vinaigrette and toasted pecans, roquefort, apples and slow roasted tomatoes. For the entre we had  Enchiladas Suizas (Mexico City style) with chicken and tomatillo cream sauce which fit our mild taste buds.  Cafe Barrio is a step up in a culinary experience from our usual default Mexican restaurant of choice, (i.e., Macayos)  and would definitely be worth a repeat in the future.
Amazing place! Very quaint. The walls have local art on them. Chances are when you come you will have to wait and man is it worth it! Get the guacamole with everything in it, trust me!

Disappointed that we weren't notified that their chiles en nogada is a seasonal dish. Not only is it highlighted on their menu, there is no mention of it being seasonal and our waiter had 3 interactions with us before we tried to order it and he then notified us that they didn't have it. Really, your restaurant specialty and what you're known for and you just mention it now? Our group of four was very disappointed since we were coming for this dish. The other food was good but paled in comparison.

So I was toying with 3 or 4 stars.  And as you can see,  I settled with four stars because I know I will be back.  So we have eyed this place for YEARS.  It has been booked marked for me since I have started yelp.  And one Sunday evening we finally decided to give it a try.  It starts off with a 45 minute wait, which I expected, but luckily we only had to wait 10 minutes.  I am glad they prepared to expect the worse, so as I braced myself for a long wait it felt like a gift when in 10 minutes we were seated and perusing the menu.  We had to try the guacamole.  You get to chose what goes in it, and the server recommended everything, which means everything you expect in a guac with something you don't expect: pomegranate seeds.  It was expensive, but fresh and very good.  Now the reason why I toyed with 3 stars.  My entree.  I had the carne tacos and hubby had the Cochinita Pibil.  I honestly though they were just okay.  Hubby RAVED about his slow roasted pork.  I found it tender, but not tasty.  My carne tacos were good enough, but for the price and all the hype I guess I had expected to be wowed more.  Service was good.  So back to toying with the stars again. Expensive Mexican food, but it was kinda worth it....  See I am trying to figure that one out.  So I need to come back and try another dish. I do think this place is more than just the 3 star definition of A-OK.  For me, it is more like 3 1/2 stars. I decided to round up to four stars, because I will be back. Also my hubby enjoyed it so much, and that makes me happy.  But this was the most reluctant four stars I have yet to hand out.

As I'm sitting here this morning casting my Zagat votes I cant help but feel underwhelmed by the selections on their "Arizona's Top Restaurants" I cant help but wonder why some of these places are on here. Is Barrio Cafe really the best of? For me, I think not.  We went with about 6 friends so we were able to try many things on the menu. However nothing even remotely stood out. Oh yes something did, the loud dining room. It was so loud we were literally shouting at one another from across the table. I love to talk over dinner so my throat was pretty hoarse afterwards.. ah yes, the waiter was a very nice looking man and was super flirty with all of us.. he got a big tip.  Otherwise I scratch my head and wonder why so many people gush over this place? Its not bad, its just blah.
Yum!! Awesome food. I had steak tacos, fries and salad, I recommend all of the above.

First of all, this place is VERY NOISY!! Is is also busy in there. Pretty packed. It is a somewhat small place & kind of cramped, but has very cool, artsy paintings on the walls, & the bathrooms are very decorative! The food is pretty good, not amazing, but not horrible, either.  The food did take a while to come out.
We always have a great meal at the Barrio. Be cautious of the restaurant bearing its name at the airport. Go for the original and skip the imitation.

Came here on recommendation during a work trip. It was truly a great experience. Their staff is so friendly and will help you pick an entree or drink that is what you are looking for. They know the flavors well and won't steer you in the wrong direction.  We split three entrees and they were all the perfect spice level. Margaritas were too good, could have sat there all night. Guacamole is freshly made at your table with a twist - they add in pomegranate! Surprisingly amazing - will be adding to my homemade guac!

Oh my goodness! This place is a diamond in the rough!  The servers are friendly, knowledgeable about the menu and give great accurate descriptions of the dishes.  Margaritas are fresh squeezed juices and perfectly mixed.  Gauc is made table-side and not in bla bla same old fashion. A nice pomegranate finish. Very nice!!  The pulled pork is unbelievably delicious and a house special.  Enchiladas with a creamy tomatillos sauce blew me away.  Go there and enjoy!

Ok, I needed to write an update.  Went back a second time for a business dinner, had the same fantastic margarita and enchiladas, but also found the parking lot in the rear.   Sorry Barrio, it's definitely 5 stars.

This place comes with great expectations due to the favorable press it receives. The neighborhood is a little dicey and finding a park was a challenge (it's in back) but once inside a saw a small bar area and a cozy dining room with most tables filled during the lunch hour. We scored a table and ordered the table side guacamole dish that most of the diners went with. The menu is not your standard Mexican fare, so fewer options than you may be used to. I went with chile Colorado with was very good. I would like to come back and try it for dinner.

The parking is in the back.  This is the best Mexican food I have ever eaten.  I would be here every week if we lived in Phoenix.  Table side guacamole was a fantastic appetizer.  My wife's carne esada tacos were great.  I had the seafood enchiladas, I would pass on these.
This place was fantastic. The mole was perfect. I may venture all the way to arizona for lunch here again....

This is very good upscale Mexican food.  My only problem is I find it hard to swallow $20 - $30 for a plate of Mexican food.  I know it is very good quality, but I feel for that kind of money I could have a better experience elsewhere.  If the price doesn't bother you, then by all means, it is very good.

I have to admit to being pretty seriously underwhelmed by Barrio Café. It wasn't awful by any means, but it wasn't worth the 45-minute wait my friend and I endured last night for a table. The guacamole was perfectly serviceable, with the addition of pomegranate seeds a very nice touch.  It was probably the best thing we ate. The other appetizer, a queso fundido, was under salted and straightforward. Likewise the Yucatan pork tacos, which I thought were utterly unremarkable. We also ordered chicken enchiladas with a black mole. I enjoyed the sauce, but my friend thought it was too molasses-y. And even so, I thought the sauce a little one-note. All chocolate, not much else.   Oh, and the tortillas? Not even in the same ballpark as Tortillaria Sinaloa. I'm telling you Baltimore, you don't know how good you've got it.

I keep going back here and forget to update.  This is hands-down one of my favorite places to eat. I even started eating guacamole - and I never liked it before.  I did read some of the other reviews that we less than 4 stars. All I can say is that many people are used to low-end Mexican food... rice and bean style. This is not that.  The mole is authentic, not the out of a can crap, and it tastes VERY different. It is somewhat of an love or hate thing... but trust me, for real mole, it is VERY good.  Looking forward to my next visit.

Fantastic food and amazing space!!! Staff were friendly and helpful and the food was very delicious and innovative! The margaritas were also great, specifically the low rider and organica! Will definitely be back!

Food so good, I can hear Angels sing! I had Chile Nogada, which was a delicious experience. Whose very in the kitchen is amazing. I was in heaven during every bite. It was full house and Ruben checked on me often.

Ate hear after a friend recommended it. It has been a long time since I enjoyed a restaurant this much. Sadly I dont remember the name of the items we got, but it was their two signature dishes. We also had the flan and churro deserts. Flan was made perfectly and this was the first time I have enjoyed a churro.  The only negative part of my visit was when I remembered that Denver doesn't have any place that is close to this good.

This is the second time I've been here, and it is absolutely excellent.  From the enchiladas suisas to the churros to even the coffee, this place is as good as Mexican food gets.  Service is top notch, and they certainly don't cut any corners on any of the ingredients used.

I came here with high hopes after recommendations from people and good reviews. My uber driver on the way said he used to work there too. Small world. I was solo and was offered a seat at the bar or table. I asked for a table and didn't have to wait long for one. I ordered the guacamole and the cochinita pibil tacos. Their two most popular dishes. The guacamole was prepared table side and I enjoyed. But it could have used more kick and more citrus. I ate it willingly but it wasn't as special as reports had led me to believe. As for the tacos, they were just ok. The pibil was surprisingly a little dry. Again for their signature dish I expected more. It's a cool spot otherwise. Lot of great artwork on the walls. But didn't live up to the hype for me.

I really like this place, The atmosphere and the food is awesome!!! Misconception that is Mexican food, the food on the menu represent the 22 Latin American countries, which is why it is called Barrio Cafe. Highly recommend a Sangria with the meal. Oh and the capirotada is always a must for desert!!!
Superb food , but terrible inattentive service!   This restaurant has so much potential , but even a good restaurant has great service.  Step it up!

The bartender was awesome. Made a great custom mezcal drink on the fly. The $28 halibut I ordered was hella overcooked, which saddened me because it's such a beautiful piece of fish and a pretty sizable portion. Also, the "pipián" was more of a cilantro cream sauce (good sauce, but don't call it pipián). The pozole was good, but not much different than my own - so props for a solid pozole! But also if I pay for it I want it to be better than what I can do on my own, and it didn't come with tortilla or tostada. Finally, the ambiance was great and felt really inviting, super warm and artsy and culturally relevant for this Texas chicana, but the service was meh - maybe our server was weeded? Overall, I was a little disappointed because I felt like there was so much there that was possible but the execution was a little off. Hope the management pays closer attention on other days! Lots of potential here.

A local hot spot in a non-hot spot. The location for this fine restaurant is a little off the beaten path, but many have found their way to this delicious establishment as there is always a crowd from the moment they open. Not your typical Mexican joint. If you are looking for basic burros or tamales or chimichangas don't look hear. If you want a selection of thoughtfully created tastes and food then you will not go wrong here.

Barrio Cafe was very good as usual. The consistency is amazing.  My fav is the  Pato en Tamarindo Seared duck breast finished with a striking sweet and sour, tamarind chipotle reduction. She is a little over priced but very good.

Seriously, not the best tacos in the country!  Also,this place is supposed to serve the community and be part of a revival process...it's just another part of gentrification with those prices.  $13 for a three tacos in the hood, really?!  $12 for a drink?!  Not ok. And it took 40mins to get our meal to the table which was sloppy.  My friend's tacos didn't have sauce on them or slices of avocado like mine, and the waiter, who was nice, didn't show up to the table to check on us.  He forgot my other friend's drink and never brought it...it was a mess. I will say however, their guac is pretty delicious.  Would I go back?  Honestly, no.

OMG!!  had the chicken enchiladas!!  they were the bomb,  I would  order this dish again.  our server was very efficient and sweet.  Live music very nice I felt like I was on vacation.  Good atmosphere clean,  and excellent food.  Yeah!   See you soon..
I was in airport for a few hours and my son chose Barrio the Arizona Burrito was amazing.  Th service was above par and the beer was cold.

Enchilada chicken, halibut , chorizo , starter salsa, guacamole etc ---- great .  Scott the server---- great.  Tried Signature Margarita and was not too great.  The sauce in the enchilada was very different and thrilling.

An interesting twist on Oaxacan Mexican food. Flavors are outstanding, portions are a bit small and prices are excessive. So restaurant if you are reading this adjust your prices. The area where you are located is cheap, you know it and I know it. If you want to charge upscale prices, make the whole experience gourmet. .....end of rant.
Don't let the name fool you, this place should in Scottsdale ! It's fine class dining

I know this is blasphemy in my hood but I didn't like Barrio Cafe.  My husband and I had been trying to make it in there for a while now but everytime we go there it's packed so we opt for something less crowded.  We finally popped in during lunch; it's pretty cozy inside.  The server was rude, anything we said he acted like he had no idea what we were talking about and never cracked a smile.  I had the pollo poblano- the sauce was lacking in flavor, chicken was dry.  For the price I was expecting something better.  I didn't even like the margarita and I've never met a drink I didn't like.  Maybe the Chingona was out?
This is definitely one one my favorite restaurants in town. The food, drinks and atmosphere is amazing!  Try the guac and Sangria for sure

i've had lunch and dinner at barrio and it was night and day.  the fish tacos at lunch are spectacular.  tons of food and everything was well prepared and fresh.  the soups here are also killer.  then dinner - what a disappointment.  my friend has THE spiciest dish i've tasted in a long time - outweighed the hottest curry i've even had lately.  the chef obviously didn't taste what they were putting out because i'd never serve something to this caliber without due warning or knowledge.  i had the seafood enchiladas, which should have been called the queso fresco enchiladas with scatterings of seafood.  TONS of cheese.  i couldn't even finish the dish because of all the cheese.  i'm not in phoenix anymore and if i go back, i'll probably stick to my guns and not go to barrio, at least not for dinner.  but i'll give them another shot...

Love! Love! LOVE this place! So ya it's in the hood but it is so good! And the decor inside is simple but the mood with the candles and live music makes it amazing! The food is delicious! I wish they had rice! But there's plenty of other sides to pick from! I been here a couple of time and will keep coming!

Chiles en Nogada: The chile was OK- for the hype this place has received i really expected more flavor/spice-but no-. it was ONE Small stuffed Chile for $24 - way too overpriced!.  the sides were mashed potatoes and almost raw zucchini slices.   I don't think i will give this place a visit anytime soon because quite frankly, i can make the Chiles en Nogada for 4 people with that price.

One of the most flavorful, friendly, and unique experiences I have ever had at an out of town restaurant. My fiance and daughter came here because we love DDD and HAD to try this place because the food looked so delicious. It was definitely not a disappointment amd to top it off, service was incredible too. If you are in town, please don't hesitate to stop in and enjoy the shrimp quesadillas- to die for!

If you went to this place without knowing it was supposed to be Mexican food and without realizing how much money you were going to pay at the end, I suppose it could have been an okay experience. Everyone who helped us was very nice, but man... the food was subpar at best. The guacamole that we saw so much praise for on here stumped us from the get go. It isn't mashed in the slightest and is instead large chunks of avocado with equally large bits of onion, pomegranate seeds, and other mix-ins. Maybe we're spoiled because we're from California, but this dish shouldn't even really be considered guacamole as far as I'm concerned. I got the carne asada tacos and my friend got the suiza enchiladas. Both very average. Neither of us got drinks, and our bill was well over $50. It was such a miss. We definitely regret stopping by and urge you to look for your Mexican food fix elsewhere.

(Lyrics - Fugees - Ready Or Not)  Ready or not, here I come, you can't hide Gonna find.... you Barrio Cafe Ready or not, here I come, you can't hide Gonna find.... you Barrio Cafe  Now that I need a taste, Bo Bites awake Those who could relate know Barrios the place Tacos with grilled skirt steak Special drinks, they make When they meet their margarita mate  If I could rule Phoenix Everyone would have to come at Calle 16 of course With pomegranite on their Guac I kick a rhyme eating tortas  I pour a sip on my palates, for the review But no don't weep, Chef Esparza's in a state to keep Thinking about the Elote that I had last week Sopas on the plate, Yelpers looked for some swag I want to eat with Mexicans from here to Tucson   I have to share my love of Barrio Cafe!  I've been to the Barrio Queen and Urbana, but this is my first run at the Cafe.  It had a more mom/pop feel and very homey compared to the more invested restaurants around town.  I wish they would have kept that feeling, but then again it's what makes Barrio Cafe so appealing.    I brought my friend from out of town to Barrio Cafe on a Saturday afternoon.  They had live music and the place was pretty busy.  We started off with some guacamole which famously introduced to me with tableside preparation and also the inclusion of pomegranate.  Still the best in town for sure!  For my entree I shot for their famous Cochinita Pibil, but taco style.  My friends ordered the Pescado Taco and Mole Enchiladas.  Overall, my marinated pork tacos definitely had some special love to it.  Warm to the bite and the pork was like butter and definitely been soaking in the achiote sauce for quite a bit of time.  The fish tacos were crunchy from the breading and the cabbage while the subtle bite of the avocado helped mellow it out from the aioli.  The mole had a strong cocoa taste, but mixed well the bland corn tortilla wrapped chicken giving a much needed flavor pop!  In the end, Barrio Cafe was voted best Mexican restaurant in the country for a reason.  It's local fare and alluring arts is well worth it as it sits in the heart of Phoenix. - Enjoy!
Good food, but super overpriced likely due to Triple D.  I was expecting more of a local joint and it was weird to have white table clothes and pay $25 at lunch for their signature chicken dish.

My co-workers and I checked out Barrio Cafe on a whim.  We almost drove right by it the first time, as it is nestled in a row of shops on 16th Street just before Thomas. There is a very very small parking lot in the back, but parking is also available on the residential street.  The restaurant looks like a hole in the wall on the outside, but inside the door is simple but very nice.  And the alcohol display when you first walk in is quite impressive!  The menu is quite large and incredibly diverse. It is not typical Mexican...I would describe it as Mexican with a flair.  I had the chicken "torta" with crab and cheese, which you can get with either a side salad or seasoned fries...I got the fries.  The chicken, cheese and crab combination was very tasty and incredibly filling. I was only able to eat about half of it and some of my fries before getting full.  The chicken was cooked to perfection and the cheese and crab complimented each other very well and neither overpowered the taste of the chicken.  Service, at lunch, was very fast, although our service was a little underwhelming.  UPDATE-January 2008  I met a group of girlfriends for dinner on a Thursday night at Barrio.  The bar area is too small to adequately hold the number of people waiting on a busy night...I felt smushed like a sardine and it was almost impossible to get to the bar to order a drink while we waited.  Plus, we had an hour wait.  Luckily, our waitress was very nice once we got seated and was more than accommodating when we paid to run seven credit cards.  I tried the garlic and tequila lobster quesadilla...I did not like it at all.  First, I don't like open faced quesadillas...second, not enough cheese for my liking.  Third, the lobster was very blah and didn't taste like it was cooked properly.  Finally, there was live music that night.  We happened to be sitting pretty close to where the musicians were set up, which made conversation almost impossible.  I'm not sure live music in such a small establishment is really a good idea.  I would definitely recommend Barrio as a lunch location, but not for dinner.

Barrio Cafe = Meh, I've had better!   We were looking forward to trying this place an now that we have, I at least can say I've them a try...  This place falls way short on the flavor-roma scale when it comes to tasty Mexican food.   We have a group of five, so we tried several things on their menu.  The first thing we noticed were the portions.  Muy pequena!  Ok, so this is different than what many of the pics on Yelp look like but maybe it's not the size that matters in this place but rather the quality of food.  Pues no, la calidad es el mejor promedio (nope the quality is average at best).  Many of the pollo and rice items were very dry.  We also had an issue with our server.  He was no where to be seen for several minutes so we had to sick the hound dogs after him to get some refills.   Anyways, this place seems to fill up with plenty of locals.  So good luck!
YES. You want to come here. It is delicious, fresh, and joyful. Things to know: it's insanely popular (for good reason) so be prepared to wait for a table, it's loud, and it's where happiness is.

Visiting from CA and this place was recommended to us. We went in for lunch and the customer service was great. This was described as a French/Mexican restaurant. After eating there, I agree. The Mexican flavors were present with a French sophistication. We had the Fillet dish and the Nogadas special. I really enjoyed the use of uncommon ingredients such as pomegranate and almonds.  $$$, good portion size and worth the money.

I try to surprise my wife about once a month with a trip to Barrio.  It's not the closest restaurant to us, but it is always worth the drive.    I've read on past reviews that people say their margaritas are expensive, true, but you get what you pay for!  At least it's not a crappy expensive marg.    Rarely do we venture far from the "Two Fish Tacos and Two Margarita 'Combo'".  We'll mix it up with chips and guac once in a while, but that is just icing on the cake.    The decor is awesome and the place is quaint.  The parking is bad and the wait is long.  Worth it?  Hell yes!    I love it when Italians work at Italian restaurants... and the same goes true for Mexican joints.  Thanks for keepin it real Barrio!

Thanks to Guy Fieri's show, I looked this place up while visiting on a business trip. The location is in an area I'd probably not want to be at night. The graffiti artwork is amazing surrounding the building.  As soon as you enter, the interior is classy and simple. The walls are adorned with more artwork.  The afternoon we were there, they had live music. They were fantastic!  Service was excellent. It was so nice to see everyone with great personalities in there.  We had the pomegranate guacamole. Interesting combo that was refreshing and light. I had the Cochinita Pibil Torta. It had me screaming oh my god with every single delicious bite! The meat was juicy and tender. The pickled onion gave it a nice tart kick and the spicy fries with that addicting chipotle ketchup sauce. Ay yai yai!!  We were in and out in about an hour so we could head on our way to continue our tour of the city. This is a MUST EAT place!

3.5 stars  This is a review by a vegetarian. The universe (i.e. pervasive marketing) was willing us towards this place. It was featured in an article in the Southwest airlines magazine; had a big ad in the hotel's guide to services; and is one of the few places on Yelp with more than a handful of reviews.  Seating was prompt and friendly. The art on the wall, though vibrant and aggressive, didn't distract. Our server resembled a very happy and enthusiastic Mr. Clean, bald, always smiling and nodding.  The lemonade tasted real. The tableside gauc was really good even though I'm usually not a fan of so much tomato. The pomagranite seeds really work. The REAL fried tortilla chips really make the dish. My only compliant is the quantity/price ratio. $8 for one avocado's worth of guac. If my buddy were into it at all we would've been fighting over it. I heard the table next to us order a second shot of the stuff.  My spinach salad was nothing special.  No place to walk afterward. The price to pay for easy parking.

YOOOO, the best place I went to when I was in AZ. they have the best horchata in a coke bottle- no lie. the food is bomb.com. I got the fish tacos with a side of seasoned fries. my bf got the pulled pork burger (which we're not usually pulled pork fans) but that was pretty good too. The burger was not dry at all and everything that it came with including the fries just went well together! I def recommend!

Wow.  Just wow!   This would be a 5 star review, but our service knocked it down a star  We waited about 45 minutes, but enjoyed the ambiance and the art work on the wall.  When we were seated, I already knew we were going to order the tableside guacamole (one of the items I found to be a bit over priced)  $12 for a pretty small bowl of guacamole.  Yes, it was fantabulous, so in the end I didn't mind paying...but it was a pretty small bowl to be shared between 3 people.  It was made very quickly (with little/no interaction from our server...when I noticed the other server in the area was laughing and explaining the process to his tables....however, our server was not the most personable of fellows...) and with very fresh ingredients, cilantro, jalapeno, pomegranate seeds...opted for no onions, and topped with fresh lime juice and seasonings.  It was delicious.  I also have to add that the tostadas that they use are fantastic.  Crispy, thick, not greasy or salty at all!  We ordered a couple of drinks, I chose my go-to drink: Michelada with Tecate.  I went picosito and it was delicious.  The right amount of hot sauce, lime juice and beer!  A friend of mine ordered the spicy margarita (which our server forgot and had to be reminded) and she loved it!    As for our meals, 2 of us chose the Mariscos enchiladas.  A white cream sauce with oaxaca cheese, bay scallops, shrimp...HUGE shrimp cooked to perfections, and crab meat.  A few hunks of calabasitas and it was ...TO...DIE...FOR!!!  The sauce really complimented the various seafood and not one of the ingredients overpowered any other.    The birthday girl opted for the carne asada tacos with spicy fries....spicy? Not so much...but very tasty!    We were stuffed.  But...it was my friend's birthday so we had to have some dessert!  We looked over the menu and before we could finish deciding, they brought over the best flan I have ever had in my life!  The consistency was ideal and it was covered with this caramel sauce and candied pecans.  Needless to say, we made room for the flan!    We were beyond satisfied with our meal, however...the service we received left a lot to be desired.  I found myself envious of the other tables who were greeted with smiles and had a server that waited for his customers to finish their sentences.  Ours made us feel as if we were a burden and he had better things to do.  He never acknowledged our orders and just walked away when we finished...almost before we finished and was always looking around instead of making eye contact.    I will be back and hopefully the service I receive will warrant me doing the well-deserved 5-star marking for this place!  Thank you Chef Silvana!  You are a gem in the Valley of the Sun!

Food was good, but not as good as I had hoped.  Just up the street is La Santisima, which was way better.  Barrio is a bit overpriced as well.  So what did we get...Cochinita Pibil is a slow cooked pork that tastes, well...like slow cooked pork!  I was expecting a bit more, and I'd say this is the dish that let me down.  Also got Chiles en nogada which was actually quite unique.  Spicy pepper stuffed with chicken and sprinkled with pomegranate - it's the one dish I'd recommend.  Both dishes had bland and forgettable sides.  Churros for dessert were okay but not great, and the horchata and frescos were good but crazy stupid over priced given they are just sugar water shaken up in a coke bottle.

I don't get the 5 star reviews. Place was very mediocre and we both felt sick afterword. The margarita was beyond sweet and undrinkable, my queso was just a chuck of melted cheese in the middle.... not worth it. Rest of the food was not even worth mentioning. Maybe the Barrio on Grand Avenue is better, wouldn't recommend this to anyone.
I love the spin on traditional Mexican food. I had the goat cheese caramel and at first it was weird, but then I loved it. The poblano was great!
Hostess was sassy and rude. We waited an hour and a half for a table. Also, the guacamole isn't anything to write home about. The spicy marg is actually just a tequila sunrise. Just go to chipotle.

Not really sure why this place has such rave reviews, maybe it's just not for me. I got the Enchiladas Suizas, which was essentially sugary chicken, cheese, and milk that tasted like a frozen microwave dinner. I love cheese and this was too much cheese. My fiancee got one of the tacos, which were alright, but not $12 good for the portions and flavors. The best part of the meal was the Guacamole, which had pomegranate seeds in it.  As for the service, it was minimal.  It was not busy at all and we waited a long time to be seated, for anyone to come take our order, for waters, and then a long time for the check - though oddly the food came fast.  I did not finish my enchiladas (I admittedly barely ate) and the waiter asked if I wanted it packed up, I said no thank you.  Later the manager came by and asked if I wanted it packed up and I said no thank you to him as well.  He asked me if I liked it and I said it was alright (I didn't want to be rude). He then launched into a story about how you should not lie and gave me literally his whole life story and how hard he has worked to get here. If he was looking for sympathy for a better tip, admittedly it worked, because based on the food and service I would have tipped on the low end.
