I left feeling a bit conned, I spent a ton of money on food I didn't enjoy, wasted my time doing a lot of waiting throughout the service, then more time (I was really trying to get to an evening appointment) when the manager lectured me on telling him if I liked his food or not and his tragic backstory. He seemed nice enough, and I sympathize, but the combination of everything left a figurative and literal bad taste in my mouth.

I don't like being tricked.  That's why Barrio's only getting 3 stars.  You sit down, and the waiter takes your drink order and caually asks you if you want some gaucamole.  Your natural response is yes, and then you discover when you get the bill that it's almost $11 for that gaucamole -- that can almost double your lunch bill.  When the waiter asks, he makes it seem like the free chips and salsa you get at any Mexican restaurant.  Sure, I should have known better, but still, I don't like getting duped.    The food is good and the service is good.  The lobster quesadilla appetizer was quite good.  I do go back because the food and the service is good, just be warned about the guac.  Oh, but the guac is really good -- it has pomegranate seeds on top.  Yummy!

This place was lovely!  As an out-of-towner, it was the perfect place to go for a local experience.  You must get there very early to get a seat, but they do have a new place outside to wait, if you have to. The guacamole was a treat - what with them making it for you at the table and including pomegranate seeds!  I ordered their "specialty" - some sort of pork dish which was ok...a little dry for my tastes.  I actually was kind of disappointed by it.  But, other than that, I give this place a solid 4 stars.  Cozy and sweet.

We were so looking forward to dining here -we were very disappointed  ! First of all you need to go into it from a back parking lot into a door that was not signed very well to know to use it. The dining room area is very small and noisy. If you want an intimate place to chat over your meal,this is NOT THE PLACE  !  With all the awards and positive things we had heard about the taste of the food and etc,we were disappointed. Either we didn't order the items on the menu that qualified for such awards or it isn't the way they say it is.  The server was nice,but didn't come back too often to check out our need for drink refills and etc. We were there for the lunch time. We noticed the cost of the dinner items,they along with others were very pricy. This place isn't located in an area of Phoenix where this pricing is justified. If in Scottsdale or other equivalent areas, then possibly but not at this restaurant. We will NEVER RETURN to this place. SAVE YOUR MONEY ! This place serves food that tastes like those of the "run of the mill" type Hispanic restaurants that dot the landscape of Phoenix and surrounding areas  !!

Stopped in on a "Sunday afternoon" with the family, first off I ordered the tacos de cochinita pibil, this is the pride of the Yucatán peninsula which is supposed to have a sweet earthy taste, not impressed not even close, also the meat was very dry. The prices were a bit high for the area where the restaurant is located. The decor; poorly neglected with cholo paintings on the walls. The tables were set much too close together. The poor kid behind me kept backing into my chair. I felt like I was eating inside an old school tattoo shop or trapped in a bad episode of The Art Laboe low rider show. If you're going to have fine dining prices maybe the decor should work in synergy with the menu prices. 11.00 for a mimosa is pretty high in my opinion. Our server was nice, pleasant and attentive. I'm a native, first time here, and we will not be back. Overrated, overpriced and a disappointment.
I loved this place since it opened. The food is always fantastic. She makes the best ketchup, you'll ever have...no joke.

This place was amazing. A bit of a wait, but that's because the food inside was worth waiting for. I ordered the chicken enchiladas with tomatillo cream sauce, and I thought I was going to die from yumminess overload. I mean, it was one of the best things I've ever had in my life, and it was DEFINITELY the best enchilada I've ever had anywhere, ever.  The guacamole made at the table was fresh, and the addition of pomegranate seeds was a little curious, but ultimately delicious.   The service was top notch, coming to check on us a few times, and again...the BEST enchilada I've ever had. Amazing.  A little pricey, but it was worth it. This is a special occasion place for special food, in my opinion. Loved it, and 5 stars.

YUM! So far this is the best restaurant I've been to in Phoenix. The service was fantastic.  They made us feel like we were visiting their house for Sunday dinner.  The guacamole with pomegranate was extremely tasty and the fresh tortilla chips were some of the best I've had.  For entrees, I was between the shrimp or the fish tacos and asked the server for his advise.  He told me he'd suprise me.  Love it! I ended up with the fish tacos and they were some of the best fish tacos I've ever had.  Coming from San Diego, that's a pretty big feat.  My husband had the chili relleno with shrimp and scallops and it was soooo tastey! I really wish we would have saved room for dessert.  The flan or the churros looked unbelievable.  Next time!  I hardly ever give 5 stars so check this place out!

Our first visit to Barrio Cafe and we LOVED it. We had prompt, friendly service and the timing of the service was spot on. The happy hour tacos and drinks were perfect. My husband tried the duck tacos and was very pleased. I preferred the halibut. Both phenomenal. Next visit we will have to save room for dessert. Oh, did I mention the sangria? YUM!

You know you're in for a fun experience as soon as you walk in the door. Vintage Mexican movie posters line the hallway, while works by local artists brighten the walls in the two dining rooms. The tables are lit by tall votive-candle glasses embossed with pictures and mini-bios of various saints. Be sure to visit the restroom - wildly painted, adorned with colorful tiles, and decorated with crucifixes, statues of the Virgin Mary, and pictures of Jesus, its somewhat irreverent and completely unexpected atmosphere is sure to stun you and make you smile. As will the food. Despite the name, there's nothing barrio about the cuisine, an eclectic mix of south-of-the-border dishes that eschews the typical combination platters that are geared towards gringo palates in favor of colonial Mexican cooking. As if to emphasize the fact that this is no Chevy's, the traditional chips and salsa are replaced by a basket of French bread with a tapenade of olives, garlic, and capers. Do not miss Guacamole Casero, which is prepared fresh tableside. A ripe avocado, moistened with olive oil, white vinegar, and a splash of balsamic vinegar, is mashed with onions, tomato, cilantro, and pomegranate seeds, and served with topopos (round, fried, chiplike corn tortillas). The chef best displays her successful break from the familiar with the entrees. Seared duck breast is sweet, spicy and tart, aided by the addition of a tamarind and chipotle sauce. Seafood enchiladas are comprised of blue corn tortillas rolled with scallops, cheese, and crab, and topped with a trio of meaty shrimp. The chile en nogada is a large poblano pepper stuffed with apples, pears, raisins, pomegranate seeds, chicken, and smothered in an almond cream sauce. The bar stocks nearly 200 brands of tequila, wine from Valle de Guadalupe in Baja California, and a variety of Mexican beers, in addition to domestic selections. The extraordinary quality of the food is not reflected in the prices - all entrees are $20.00 or less.

It's funny how the service can make or break an evening.   I'm a pretty easy going guy with a pretty high tolerance level, however if you piss off the wife you instantly are on my shit list! Starting obviously with the service, overall in the restaurant it seemed fine but our waiter Gabe was pretty bad. I wasn't sure if he really wanted us to be there. Do you care? Do you not want a tip? Is this your civil service?   On to the food...By far the best dish was the Quesadilla with Langostine Borracho. The langostine was cooked to perfection, it did have a bit of shell but that is something I can deal with. The goat cheese is the flavor that really put it over the top. Nice dish!   The chicken mole was also a winner, however it was lacking in quantity  department with the mole sauce. If you get this dish you typically are ordering it primarily for the sauce. Don't skimp!   The prices are also a bit hefty. The two ladies next to us got their bill and gasped, "$95 for the two us!" I don't think you should be surprised by the bill, after-all the prices are on the menu, however be forewarned!   They should get a 4 star for their food but unfortunately the service is still part of the deal. I would go back if I lived in the area minus Gabe to give it another shot.

For all the hype I can't say I was especially impressed. Maybe we had the wrong items but it seemed a bit pricey, a bit smarmy and definitely overrated. The service wasn't great, the food was ok.  I went once and never felt compelled to return. Perhaps one day I'll venture back. Perhaps not...

Barrio Cafe is an amazing Mexican restaurant.  Chef Silvana Salcido Esparza travels to Mexico for many of her ingredients and you can tell - things are always fresh (they only have an ice cream freezer!), creative and authentic.  I am more than content w/ a mango margarita, the incredible guacamole and the gooey caramel filled churros!!  Even when the restaurant is packed, the staff is friendly and informative.

I've heard about this restaurant few times in the past so finally, I decided to try it out with my friend. The main reason for a 3 star rating was the level of service. Other than that, the food was average to good, and the restaurant itself was very quaint.  For parking, there is some parking in the back and there is a lot of street parking. Once parked, there is a front entrance located on the main road and there is an entrance in the back, entering from the parking lot. The host/hostess is in the front so you'd have to go there to get seated. The restaurant itself has a nice authentic ambiance to it and has an interesting layout. It has several different rooms with seating so it's not an "open concept." It's not a problem. I actually like it but just pointing it out.  Anyway, once we were seated, our service was very absent and slow. It took a while for our waitress to do everything from bringing over menus, water, our food, etc...Her presence was lacking. For the prices we were paying for food, I had expected better service. Speaking of pricing, it was slightly pricey but the food was good. It wasn't the best I've had but I liked that my food wasn't overly greasy. It was tasty and had a good portion.

Well i been here food is good however the food can be a little bit overpriced.  Plates are huge maybe thats why so they can charge u 18 $ 19$ a plate. I only went there once. The one on 16st n thomas.

None better.  I've probably eaten here 10 or more times with various groups of people, and each time everyone involved was thrilled.  Here are some rules of thumb for a happy experience...1. Small crowded dining room with tile floor = lots of noise, so don't come here expecting explain the last ten years of your life to your half-deaf grandfather.  2.  Expect to wait...in the meantime, have a delicious margarita or three.  3.  Get the guacamole...worth every penny, especially when pomegranates are in season.  4.  Skip the bread...it's a Mexican restaurant after all.  5.  Pork tacos or enchilada suiza are the best things on the menu.  6.  Check out the restroom...be inspired.   7.  If you don't like this place, stop coming back so my wait will be shorter!
Nice but not elegant atmosphere.  Cloth table coverings, great service and the food was very good.  Heavy on the onions but still good.  Definitely will go back even tho 40 miles away.

Incredible!  The chile en nogado is one of the most unique, creative, and tasty foods I've eaten. The enchilada suizas use grilled and tender chicken, a lovely flavor. But really, the nogado is memorable!! Bravo!

What the heck, I just ate 15 minutes ago, and just searching for Barrio Cafe made me hungry for their guacamole, which is prepared at your table, mixed in with pomegranate seeds. Yeah...you've read right...POMEGRANATE SEEDS. Who thinks of adding that to guacamole? My oh my...the combination with sweet and savory just did wonders to my taste buds.  I had their Chiles en Nogada, which was recommended by the waiter. Oh wow. I seriously have never been served Mexican food like this before. Again, the beautiful battle of sweet and savory. Savory being the chicken and the chile. Sweet being everything else- apples, pecans, pears, apricots, almond sauce.   They had live music as well, so in case your sense of taste is in overload, relax for a sec and switch to your sense of hearing.  By the way...I LOVE THEIR SMALL PARKING LOT! It looks so dingy-ish, and since from the parking lot you enter the restaurant in the back...makes it feel like you're in on a scrumptious secret. Plus, the street wall art was extremely colorful...almost a hint to what your taste buds will experience, and enjoy.  Warning for huge groups...it's on the smaller side.
Carne Asada tacos are AMAZING! So happy I found this place just a few minutes away from my work

Outstanding Chile En Nagado!  Went in on Mother's Day and was not disappointed!  There was a little wait time, so they brought out delicious guacamole and chips as well as bread with a tapenade.    I had the lime water which was so refreshing and the Chile En Nagado which was delightful!  I only had it twice before in Mexico and each version is a little different. What a joy!  My daughter and son in law went with the breakfast items... so many egg dishes to choose from but I was on a mission.  We invited a single elderly patron to join us.  He gave us the low down on the menu as he has visited frequently for Baseball season.  Ha ha he had 2 breakfasts and menudo that was a lot of food!  I was super happy it was flavorful without being spicy.  My kids dishes were very spicy for them.  Everyone has a difference in tolerence,  I'm all about flavor instead of spice.  My side dishes of squash and potatoes were delightful as well.  To be honest I boxed half and had the other part for dinner, so excellent portion sizes!  We enjoyed the live music as well.  The staff was great.  I would rather it take awhile and have fresh delicious food than mediocre food quickly!  I'm definitely coming back. I picked up an order of the Chile En Nagado to go for my Father and he was delighted as well!    **note  to self parking and entrance is in the rear of building.
Authentic yet upscale Mexican food, with a mole sauce to DIE for! This place is a little pricey, and popular on evenings and weekends, so better make a reservation.

While there are some interesting twists with the menu, the abysmal service here would overwhelm even the highest quality food. The guacamole topped with pomegranate seeds was nice and interesting. The cochinita pibil was disappointing. The spice blend of that dish overwhelmed the meat rather than enhanced it. The plate presentations were consistently sloppy and generally were a good metaphor for the overall lackadaisical experience. But the service was what will prevent us from returning. Our waiter "Marcos" acted as if he'd rather be wallowing in pig manure than waiting on us. Even something as minor as getting a drink refill seemed to require an act of Congress. He even brought the change back in a wet folder.  Apparently being featured on a Food Network show has inflated the egos of the staff here. The food here isn't all that impressive. The service is what will really leave a bad taste in your mouth. Not worth the hype, the wait or your money.
Had their chorizo con huevos and pressed coffee, great atmosphere, local art on the walls and rustic.
Not even worth it.. $130 for a family of 4. This is the PF Chiang's or worse of Mexican Food.. $5 horchata and $10 Churros? Comedor dela Guadalajara is still the bomb...

We went here for lunch because the cafe was featured on DDD. If you are looking for a "dive" with "dive" prices you will be disappointed. But if you are looking for a white tablecloth gourmet experience this is your place. I had the famous chile en nogado and it was deliciously interesting. Having just hiked Camelback mountain I could have used more food, which I expected for the price. My husband had tacos with the specially prepared pork. They were good.  Great service.

I have actually eaten here several times. I am a big fan of the food, however, every time I come in, the service is just lacking. We won't let that keep us from continuing to eat here, as maybe it has just been bad luck on our end. Looking forward to our next visit.

Wow the food here is fresh, super authentic and burst of with flavor. The area seems like the edge of the ghetto but it was still good. Staff was friendly and the art work on the wall made for good table conversation. Highly recommend coming to this place.

This is not the typical burrito and enchilada joint most people envision when thinking of Mexican food. It's much much better and brings together flavors from all over Mexico.  Barrio Cafe is not for everyone. If you have no sense of adventure or want standard fare, go to a chain or a drive-through. Want something different, yet absolutely delicious? Come here with an open mind and try as many different things as you can.

I had the  cochinita  pibil -  it's  pork ( Puerco asado) slow roasted  overnight ;w/ achiote &  sour  orange  wrapped in a banana leaf , pickled red onion &  pico de gallo topping. The  portion was plentiful &  enough to take home &  enjoy a  sandwich the next  morning  at  Sky Harbor  Airport.  The  spicy  mashed potatoes &  zucchini  side dishes  came w/ the meat & were very tasty. The Barrio Bomba  margarita was excellent  w/  orange  juice &  pineapple juice , &  Cointreau.  My  dining  partner  enjoyed her Pollock  of Pescado el  dia, also.  Our  server , Aaron , was friendly &  explained  the menu items . Chef Silvana Salcido Esparza was at the café  & it's  terrific to know  that she is an humanitarian as well.
Amazing. That is all you need to know. Make sure you try the sopa de chile marron'. Phenomenal. Great service here, the bonus.

CLOSED MONDAYS. Not in a great part of town. Park in back, or across the street. The day we visited CNN was doing a piece on the chef. Try the Guacamole (it has Pomegranate seeds) w very fresh tortillas). Filete de Tita ($26) Filet Mignon with Mash Potatoes with chorizo, Crab, Blue Cheese (smoky, Flavorful, spicy). Some overcooked some undercooked. Definitely get dessert &  coffee (big French press with a very robust coffee) a must is the Churros filled with Caramel.

This place is a true gem in Phoenix! Easily a top restaurant in the valley. We had the fresh guacamole made table side, the enchiladas suizas and the carne asada and pork tacos. We all kept looking at each other with amazement by how good everything was tasting. The place is small and quaint, but the ambience is so nice. They don't take reservations, so you may have to wait. But it's so worth it! Will definitely be back!

Holy cow! This place had my expectations super high. Was very dissapointed. Got the table side guac, was ok. Could make the same at home. Had both dishes shown on DDD. Wasn't super impressed. Sangria, was good, but not excellent.   This place is extremely small. There was a two hour wait. So husband and I killed our time going to the arcade bar down the street.   Was expecting a lot more from this place.

Went here on a Saturday at 7:30pm. We were a party of 2 and had to wait an hour and a half for a table.  Because of the expected wait, we left and came back after~30-40minutes. I think you have to let them know you're coming back so they don't assume you've given up. I agree that the waiting area is very small when busy. If it wasn't so cold outside, I wouldn't have minded sitting on the benches. I guess you have to be really patient!  Food: I got the tacos de pescado (fish tacos) and my friend got the cochinita pibil (slow roasted pork). My dish came with either a side salad or fries; i opted for the salad. The tacos were delicious. The fried halibut was not too greasy and the avocado was fresh and ripe! The drizzle of chipotle cream sauce was just enough to give it a little spice. Yummy! I tried my friend's pork, and I didn't enjoy it as much as my dish. He had a side of something that was SUPER spicy!!!!! I don't remember what it was called but it kinda resembled mashed potatoes. Portions were a good size, not too little, not too much.  For dessert, we shared the Churros. I was a little hesitant because I read it was filled with goat's milk caramel. I love churros, and i love caramel, but goat's milk caramel? I was pleasantly surprised. The churros were divine! I think it may have been too much for us since we'd eaten all of our food. But I'd say definitely go for the Churros if you have a little  room in your belly!!!!  The place was a little loud since they had live music and lots of people. The decor was nice, not super fancy which I like.  Our server was very helpful in my choice of dish.    PROS: great fish tacos. AWESOME churros. good service. CONS: Wait during busy times (they don't take reservations either...boo), parking is supposedly tough since parking lot in the back is quite tiny though. We were able to park down the street no problem.

I will give it 5 starts as the food is awesome !!! Incredible good and specially the dessert. The cajeta sweet crepe is over the top. Sadly, the service is the worst I have ever seen in my entire life. The hosted is a grumpy, rude and lack of manner girl that also wrote down my name as a female and when I corrected her she just make fun of it. The waiters are terrible to the extend that the guy throws the guacamole all over the table. I did tip well :-)

Love me some Barrio.  The Barrio is one of those restaurants that you bring your visiting friends and relatives to. The place is tiny for sure and you most likely will have to wait, but have a cocktail and enjoy the atmosphere. The food is more from Southern Mexico and completely different from the other options in town. I have loved everything I have ever tried here. The guac that they make at your table is a nice show for visitors and natives alike. The service is always good and the crowd is always lively. Give it a try sometimes, you will be glad you did.
Food was different but very delicious. Aaron was great! He made eating here a great experience.

Okay the first time there last Saturday, recommended by coworker Maria wife of Yolie who know the owner.  Popped in about 330 pm told half out wait.  Was able to squeeze in at the bar.  Let me just say Richard is fantastic.   Kinda over did it on the food, appetizer stuffed jalapeños- great.  Then the pozole-fantasti.  Went for a double main,  the filet and the Verde enchiladas.  The file cane with a red and red wine reduction sauce jalapeño mad and calabasas or zucchini wowsa. The verde enchiladas had grilled tortillas and a wonderful sauce.  Topped it off with the vanilla stuffed churros with ice cream, Carmel and whipped cream.    The food was wonderful, really busy now during the season.  Will be back want to try the brunch.  Definitely will be back again.

It's pretty good but a little pricey for what you get..the tacos are really small!  Good flavor..I had carne asada tacos..u get 4 small tacos..very tasteful but tiny..finished dish in like 2 minutes!  The Jamaica Margarita was pretty good but also small..it had Gran Mariner in it which was a nice kick! ($13)..another thing is that the server barely payed attention to us and was only looking after the larger tables.

Wow! The food here definitely got my nipples hard! They served some kind of mashed potato and it was super flavorful! Pozole was hearty and the entree was amazing (I don't know what it was but it was tender and packed with flavor!)

The two things that jettison my brain into a Barrio Cafe daydream are:  1)  The Sangrita 2)  The Churro dessert  In fact, if this place was called "Barrio Sangrita and Churro Shop", i would still want to run up to the building and give it a big hug.  Really, enough has been said here about the food, or atmosphere, or whatevs ... but if they're hoping to leave a legacy in Phoenix, its with these two items.  I prefer going to BC for brunch on Sunday.  I enjoy that menu the best.  Oh, and the table side Guac is a nice touch.

Wow.  The perfect combination of creative and authentic.  Small, funky, hip and intimate.  Great service, killer ingredients, and a fun atmosphere.  We literally loved this place; oh, and we are serious foodies.  Guacamole was a fresh spin on a classic, yet truly scrumptious.  We devoured it.  Tacos - slow roasted Mayan pork - were crazy delicious.  The serving was 4, with double corn tortillas, so I divided them and made 8 tacos - holy mackerel, they were good!  My wife won the Mexican food lottery, however: Chile Relleno Nogales or something like that.  It was sweet and spicy; a chile stuffed with cheese, fruit, nuts, and lightly layered in a sweet, nutty sauce.  Literally the best Mexican dish I've ever tasted (including in Mexico itself).  It combined the best of savory and sweet.  We didn't leave a single morsel on the plate.  Amazing.  Tip:  order a simple margarita (off the menu), with tequila, lime and agave nectar.  So simple, yet so tasty.

A couple of co-workers and I ventured out to the "Barrio" this afternoon for lunch.  If you do plan to go for your lunch hour, carpool with co-workers because parking is very limited and plan for an extended lunch because you very well might spend over an hour here. We showed up at noon, not packed at all, however, our service was very slow. The time it took our server to take our order, deliver our food and drop our check seemed way too long. The seating is uncomfortable and may be a little crowded for those with space issues.   However, the food is great! If you're one to overlook the aforementioned cons, then you will love the Barrio hands down! In lieu of chips and salsa, you will be served bread and tapenade. Try the Guacamole, made fresh upon order and is served with tostada chips. This Gauc is really good!!!!  I had the Torta de Pollo - grilled chicken breast served on a warm pannini style bread and slathered with great flavors. But wait! Don't stop there.. You have got to leave room for  Postres! OMG!!!!! The Churros Rellenos KICK!!!! These are not to be confused with the Churros you may have had at Disney Land. These Churros are served with warm caramel sauce, vanilla bean ice cream and candied walnuts. It is a crime to not have these fritters.    I struggled giving 5 stars because of the lack of parking, slow service, and uncomfortable seating. However, This will not stop me from making another trip to the Barrio.    See you there!

The food makes this place. Everything was delicious. We had the carne asada tres tacos, and the poblano torta. The food was pricey compared to most places and the quality of meats, cheese and veggies explain why. It was packed when we got there and the service was a bit slow however not bad. Do not expect a turn and burn or fast food atmosphere take your time and enjoy. That reminds me the seats are not the most comfortable and your packed into a small room all that aside the food and drinks are worth the trip especially if you have never been there.

We came here for HH.  Great selection and reasonable priced.  The regular menu is a bit pricey for the amount you get but the food is good.  The place is small and you bump chairs with your fellow diners.  I got the Pescado Tacos, good but small portion.  The service was awesome!
Always good. Sometimes have to wait awhile to get a table but has always been worth it. Go early if you don't want to wait to long for a table.

I had been wanting to try this place for years, but living in chandler we don't make it up that way all too often.  Last week though my 13 year old had an ATV accident and was moved to phoenix children's hospital.  3 nights in, the bf and I were sooooo tired of the cafeteria food that we decided to duck out for a real dinner while the boy was sleeping.  A quick yelp search and I saw that Barrio Cafe was within walking distance!  Score!  So we headed out.  Now being from chandler, we were caught a little off guard as we approached the intersection of Thomas and 16th st.   We weren't in the suburbs anymore, that's for sure.  As we headed down 16th st. past the graffiti and storefronts with bars on the windows, we started wondering if we should have driven.  But then 50 ft ahead we saw the restaurant.  Yes!  We got there around 5:15 so it wasn't busy and we were seated immediately.  Cute place.  Small, charming, with a cute, but really small wood bar by the entrance.  Our waiter came by right away and recommended the Lowrider margarita so we each ordered one.  This is a very authentic tasting margarita.  Lots of tequila, a little bit of lime.  Very strong...but at $12 bucks a pop we each only needed one.  They brought out bread with an olive tapenade, I think.  Really good!  I knew I wanted to try their table side guacamole with the pomegranate seeds and I'm glad we did!  Very yummy!  Great chips too!  Our waiter made some great recommendations, but knowing we were already going to be almost full from bread and guacamole, we opted for tacos.  I had a combo order of the shrimp tacos and the halibut.  The bf got the tacos de carne asada.  Everything was fabulous!  You get 4 with each order and I had to discard the tortillas after two so I could finish them.  They come with either fries or salad.  We were confused about fries coming with tacos, but that's a Spanish thing I guess, so the bf got fries, I got salad.  Great little salad, but boy were those fries good!  They come with a chipotle ketchup and just taste great!  All in all, a great meal, and a great distraction from the stress of my son's accident.  I'd definitely like to go again and try something other than the tacos.  Btw....the boy is ok.  Recovering nicely!

If you have been to Barrio Cafe, you know what I'm going to say. If you haven't, get there immediately. You won't find better Mexican food. Ever. But don't expect chips and salsa and a burrito. This place is authentic Mexican, with a French twist. The chiles en nogada is the signature dish here; it's a symphony of flavors your palette has never experienced. But that's just the beginning. Also try the pescada del mar, which is a wonderful blend of fish, crab, scallops and chorizo. The house made guacamole is fantastic, and don't forget the churros with goat's milk caramel for dessert. Simply the best. Chef Silvana is a culinary genius.

Guacamole with pomegranate seeds made table side is amazing!  Salad with dinner so good.  We were a walk in party of 5 and didn't have to wait too long while every table was filled.  Unique menu.  Three taco choices were ample and tasty.  Carmel Churros unbelievable dessert!  Elegant Mexican dining.

The menu cover was right. "Comida chingona" is the only way to describe the cuisine here. Although I had a savory experience, the service was at times awkward. Was my server having a bad day? Hungover? Tired? I don't know, but he didn't make me feel comfortable. At one point he just left without letting me know someone else would be taking care of me. I was waiting for him to come back and he never did. Another man just started talking to me and I didn't even know he was my new server.  Anyway, let's not punish the food on behalf of my server's lack of professionalism. Yes, they served bread with tapenade instead of chips and salsa. So? I was actually happy to see something else being offered. Everyone can serve that, but tapenade? I've actually never had it before but have been meaning to try it. Now I know what it tastes like. Be open to try new things, even at a Mexican restaurant.  I ordered the corn chowder and chile en nogada for my meal. The chowder was probably the best thing out of this whole ordeal. It was sweet without being overbearing and it had a similar taste to a warm cup of cornmeal. I've had corn chowders before but this was different. The corn was definitely the distinguished guest. I didn't even care about the shrimp. It was that good.  I love chiles rellenos and have always wanted to try the other variation: chiles en nogada. Unfortunately I've had a tough time seeing them in menus until now. It took a while for it to be cooked, but the wait was worth it. Albeit, the chile itself is not spicy, the contents are sweet and fresh. Chicken combined with raisins and other fruit was a different spin to Mexican food. I'm all about spice and heat, and I liked the cooler aspect of this dish. The almond sauce is light and the pomegranates add tiny explosive bursts of flavor.  The side vegetables were good as well. I'll be honest though, this was the first time I've seen a Mexican restaurant serve mashed potatoes as a side dish. But hey, I'm open to new things! I loved the idea of having the horchata inside recycled Coke bottles. It was refreshing in both concept and flavor. I don't like too much sugar, and this horchata had the perfect sweetness to it. What I would do for some corn chowder and horchata from a Coke bottle...  I was REALLY tempted to try the churros filled with cajeta, but I didn't dare. I was extremely full. Thank you for the food, even though I had to put up with some messed up service to obtain in.

One of the best meals I have enjoyed since living in Phoenix (1 year so far). Didn't know what to expect. Originally I was thrown off as they serve complimentary bread instead of chips- but to my delight, the ciabatta with olive tapenade was "deelish." My spicy margarita was outstanding.  Our super personally server suggested I go with the chicken molé--- FANTASTIC! I was so full but I couldn't stop- it was like crack.  Thank you. I will be back.

We had dinner at Barrio Cafe based from reviews posted. We arrived at 4:00 and finally left at 6:15. Very slow service. Food was ok and overpriced. We will not visit Barrio Cafe again when there are other Mexican Restaurants equally good and affordable.

You ever have an experience where in the middle of it, you realize that you are at the pinnacle - the zenith - of that particular type of experience?  It was my last night in Phoenix and hap and circumstance led us to Barrio Cafe.  My Karma must be fabulous right now, as I tell you without hyperbole that it was the best meal I have ever had.  Filet mignon topped with Mexican crab meat and goat cheese coupled with two top shelf margaritas. I almost balked as I think the margaritas were $9 and the steak $25-ish (more than I'm usually inclined to spend) but hey - last night of the vacation so why not.  I tried to savor it, but I just wanted to gorge myself on it.  It was so tasty that words fail me.  I know that some day if I find myself on death row, this is the meal I will request.  I will not be surprised if the sheer ecstasy of the meal kills me first.

It seems kind of funny to me that both in Seattle and Phoenix, you have to wait in line for half an hour for good Mexican food.  In any case, I we lucked out and hit the Barrio on a Friday morning around 11.  It was busy, but no problems landing a table.  I grabbed a peach margarita and would have to say it was not only worth the $7, it would have been worth $17.  For lunch, the carne asada and pork tacos were both outstanding.  Also a nice surprise was the fries with super tangy chipotle sauce.    A little busy, a little pricey, but I don't think you'll mind either once you get a taste of the menu here.

I had a great meal here again! I started off with their Crema de Elote soup which is a delicious corn chowder topped with spice-rubbed shrimp. It was sweet, salty, warm with little pieces of corn which gave it a nice texture. It was a delicious, perfect soup!  I also got their famous Chile en Nogada. It's a roasted large green chile pepper stuffed with pieces of chicken and dried fruit in this red sauce, topped with a delicious, creamy almond sauce. All the flavors were perfect together, I especially liked the creamy almond sauce. Definitely unique and delicious!  I couldn't finish the horchata, served in a Coke bottle, so got that to go. All in all a delicious meal. Several tables around me got multiple orders of their tacos so that seems pretty popular. Glad I came back again!  Also, they have a location at the airport, I was flying Southwest so if you can't eat here for some reason, you can at least grab the same food at the airport!

This is my first yelp review and I couldn't think of a better place to pop my proverbial cherry. So I am a creature of habit and the two times I have been to Barrio I think I have gotten the same exact meal from start to finish. I would say hands down just as good as the first time!   Let me start by saying I had never tried guacamole in my life due to the look of the consistency of it. I have a problem with that with some foods. But what better way to try something then being called out by a chick. So, I tried it and it was amazing! Now not having anything to compare it to may make this less reliable, but... The pomegranate that they mash into it was great. It sort of cut through the creaminess. I had the Adobo Pork and for those meat-eaters out there it will not disappoint. For dessert I have had the churro. Unbelievable! For those of us that have only had a fair or Disneyland churro in our lifetimes, this was like a religious experience. It is served very warm with cinnamon ice cream I think.   Be prepared to wait for a table or go later in the night because it is smaller and very popular. Oh yeah, the Sangria is tasty!!!
The type of Mexican food you would find deep in Mexico... Not all fried like most Mexican places. So fresh and amazing!!!!

Stopped in here after a day at the water park because hubby was craving mole. We knew they served it here but had never tried it before. We were seated at a table and the waiter came to take our drink order after a little bit of a wait. We both ordered sangrias and we both loved the taste of them. They brought us a basket of bread with an olive tapenade that was quite tasty. We decided to start with the tableside guacamole that I had heard so much about. It was very good and the addition of the pomegranate seeds made it in my opinion. Hubby ordered the chicken enchiladas with mole sauce. It came with a side of calabasitas (zucchini and corn). To be honest he wasn't that impressed with it. The mole sauce was a bit too strong and tasted a little burnt. I had ordered the Chiles en Nogada which the waiter had recommended and it was divine. Unfortunately we did not save room for dessert however we did order two of their Horchatas to take with us. They were just as good as a dessert I could've easily have a drink another one. All in all we did enjoy our meal and will probably be back!

First of all, my disclaimer is that I think I would have enjoyed Barrio Cafe much better as a smaller group. We were a group of 10 and knowing that they didn't take reservations, we were expecting to wait so that wasn't a real issue. However we did wait over an hour while every other group of 5 or less walked in the door and was seated immediately. I have worked in the restaurant business so I know that it isn't easy to seat large parties in a small dining room, but what was a little disappointing was that once we were seated, the service was slow. It took us quite a while to get drinks at the table and even water was a bit of a wait. Then ordering our food was another wait. The restaurant was constantly busy so my thought is that maybe they are under-staffed.  That being said, the bartender was great. While waiting for over an hour in their tiny bar space, we were served appetizers and drinks. The drinks are terrific and their tequila selection, impressive! However, I was underwhelmed by the food and we had mixed responses at the table. I ordered the Granada con Flor de Jamaica - A large pork chop served with pomegranate and hibiscus flower port reduction, crispy shallots and a candied hibiscus flower. I thought the sauce was fantastic and the pork chop was quite good, but slightly overcooked for my liking. (I know people still prefer their pork somewhat well done, but it doesn't need to be!) I don't recall crispy shallots, but maybe I missed them. The potatoes served with the dish were very tasty but barely warm and the zucchini side was - eh. Some of the other dishes at the table were the  Enchiladas del Mar - Blue corn tortillas filled with quesos Oaxaca and de cabra, topped with shrimp, lump crab and scallops in a tomatillo cream reduction. Way too heavy on the cheese for my taste (and the person who ordered it). The Pollo en Mole - Spice rubbed, pan seared chicken breast topped with a bold and flavorful Mole de Oaxaca was good. Again the sauce was a winner.   So there is definite talent in the kitchen, but not a home run for me or my guests. If I were local, I would probably try them again with a group of 4 or less. Being an out-of-towner, there are too many other spots to try in the area, so it may be a while before I return.  P.S.  I just realized their menu says "grilled to order" under the pork chop entree's. I was never asked how I wanted it grilled so that could have resolved the "too well done" issue for my pork...

Great food their pork is awesome !!!!  The slow cooking made this dish superb.   Of course the margaritas are as good as they get! Overall everyones food was tasty and the service was great.  The place was very busy with allot of energy.

I think this is the first time I've ever praised a restaurant for its tortillas.  They were the highlight of my pork tacos for sure.  The flavor and seasoning of the pork was all there, but I was surprised by how the meat appeared cubed instead of shredded.  Perhaps it contributed to the few tough pieces I chewed?  If I were to do it again, I think I would have tried the shrimp tacos or one of the enchiladas.

Such a treat! My first visit to ArIzona and I wanted great food! Well we got more with the colorful decor and the lively atmosphere.  This is not traditional "combination" dinner plate Mexican restaurant.  The menu is created by a Chef, and adventurous one who knows how to pull all the unusual ingredients together.  For starters the table-side prepared guacamole included pomegranate seeds. Odd, but delicious. Also the free starter was sliced French bread with a delicious Italian inspired tomatoe and onion relish.   My halibut with puréed hibiscus flowers was very good... Although the fish was slightly over cooked.   I enjoyed the  variety of freshly made homemade Mexican.

Not your standard Mexican food here so be prepared. I had the chicken enchiladas with a green tomatillo sauce with Mexican crema. Not spicy but very tasty and they will definitely fill you up. Had the guacamole as well which is made table side with pomegranate seeds. Sounds weird but it's as actually very good. Try it. Also had a frozen mango Margarita. Made very well. This place will have you look at Mexican food in a different way. A good way.

Excellent Mexican cuisine. Staff were friendly! The environment is fun with live music and always busy atmosphere. I had the house margarita and I was impressed by the bartender attention to detail and being a good bartender. He noticed a piece of cilantro fell into my margarita and immediately took it away and made me a new drink even though I said it was fine and I would drink it that way. He than responded with I want you to have the absolute best margarita not a just fine margarita. We didn't wait too long for a table and was sat 30 minutes later. (No reservations) the food was so good we got the queso Blanca dip for appi and I got chile pollo poblano in white sauce it was so yummy! Would totally recommend coming to try this restaurant out!!

Four stars due to the generally very good but way too loud live music.  We were unable the hear the waitress or the other couple at our table.  Appetizer included very tender shrimp and fresh corn tortilla. The expensive guac was excellent as usual, but the roll up cart for the guac production would not fit in between the tables so we missed the " show."  The drinks at the bar were fresh tasting and refreshing considering the 110 degree heat. My mole chicken was tender, the sauce appropriately spicy. Churro desert was split between four adults.  Lots of chocolate and caramel, although churro was not crispy.  Overall fun for groups.

Ok, I'm going to keep it honest. This place let me down. Big time.  I started by ordering a couple drinks. I had the La Bomba & my boyfriend went for their Lowrider. My drink was eh good? His tasted like pure tequila. I mean it was top shelf but still.. He wanted a mixed drink not shots of tequila.   Their complimentary bread and salsa was odd to me. I kept an open mind and dived in. Just wrong.. The salsa had an extremely unique taste. Honestly it shouldn't even be considered salsa. We ordered they infamous guacamole, BLAND. I'll just stop there with the apps.     I ordered their camaron tacos w/ a side of spicy papas. Pretty tasty. But nothing life changing.   The atmosphere.. Where to start. They had a band? that night which had the volume on waaaay to high. The gentlemen sitting at the table behind us was literally yelling at the top of his lungs to converse with his company. It was ridiculous. Our waitress even rolled her eyes towards the direction of the music and made a comment which of course I couldn't hear over the noise.   We skipped dessert.. Unfortunately. Due mainly to the fact that during our entire meal we were waited on by our waitress maybe twice. Once when we ordered and second to drop off the check. Pathetic. If it wasn't for her 20% gratuity that they so gracious added on themselves, she would have received close to nothing for a tip.   And that concludes my Barrio Cafe review. I really looked forward to dining here but that was the first and last time I will be visiting this restaurant.

THE BEST MEXICAN FOOD IVE EVER HAD ANYWHERE!  And I'm a huge foodie who has eaten at a lot of great Mexican restaurants. This is my family's all time favorite restaurant!  No, it's not cheap, but YOU GET WHAT YOU PAY FOR!  Incredible food from an incredible chef. Believe the hype.  There is a reason why chef Silvana has been written up in various magazines and has been nominated multiple times for a James beard award. Notable items on the menu include- guacamole, the elote appetizer, all soups on the menu are to die for, the pescado del mar, the seafood enchiladas, the cochinita pibil, The low rider margarita, and all of their desserts( in particular the churros). I've never had anything here I didn't think was amazing!

I had the green Chile Posole (Hominy & Pork soup/stew), the soup was great. The service was excellent and very friendly as a friendly neighborhood café should be. Our waiter was an ex-boxer and we talked for a while on his experiences in San Diego, Ca. It was a great experience, I would most definitely go back again.

The fish tacos were the best we've ever had! We went on a busy Sunday lunchtime and everyone else was having brunch but we had heard amazing things about their tacos. We ordered pork carnitas, carne asada, and pescado tacos. All were delicious but the fish was the best. Service was friendly and fast.

The fish tacos here are freakin awesome.  I also had a dish that was a pepper stuffed duck and pomegranite that was soo good.  Again, Phoenix food is terrible except the mexican food (see review for Los Sombrero's).  Their isn't a lot of seating available so reservations are a plus.  Also, no chips and salse, instead bread and tapanade.  That loses some points, but the fish tacos and other food make up for it.  Desserts are so-so, but mexican dessert isn't really my thing.

The area looks rather ghetto but the restaurant itself is fantastic. The best thing is the salsa cart where you can pick and choose your own ingredients and the waiter will make it fresh for you right there. It's rather pricey but consider your other options are Sonics are places with so-so tasting diner-style food, it's worth it.  I really enjoyed the live music and would definitely return here again if I'm ever in town.

Everything Chef Silvana creates is a masterpiece. While known for its playful and street savvy "Comida Chingona" tagline, there is no denying that the Barrio brand is home to the most sophisticated dishes in all of Arizona.   Their pomegranate laced guacamole is my favorite, along with the Camaron Borracho quesadilla (garlic and tequila shrimp with goat cheese on tiny corn tortillas). Simply unbeatable. It's outrageous to read some of these lukewarm reviews and proves that although progressing nicely, this city still needs guidance on recognizing the many styles of Mexican cuisine. So what if there aren't yellow cheese topped Chimichangas on the menu.. That's the beauty of it!   Of all the exquisite projects Chef Silvana brings to life, this particular location will always be my favorite. In addition to its edible offerings, Barrio Cafe showcases the works of Arizona's most respected artists, a community collaboration known as "Calle 16". This genuine love and celebration of culture is in a word, inspiring.

Mere words cannot describe the wonderful meal we had at Barrio. The mole was fresh and so light you could identify each component. Service was attentive and eager to explain the menu. This food was made with love and decades of tradition.

Just another tourist visiting Barrio Cafe. Lovely restaurant, with excellent service and approachable menu, though a little expensive.  I do think is a must try place after eating here like most of the guides say.  Agua de Horchata: I could drink this all day. I usually don't like cinammon but it worked so well with the rice water. Gotta figure out how to make this :)  Guacamole del Barrio: made table side at dinner, comes with chips. Guac was so fresh and clean.   Suiza Enchiladas: the white sauce is truly incredible.  The chorizo and chicken were nicely seasoned and cooked. It is really filling.

The food is good ... but a bit over priced, even though the portions are large. I have eaten there several times. The Barrio Cafe is very small. So if you are looking for an intimate spot, this is not it.

The food is as good as everyone says it is...it's just another level here. Guacamole is a must- with the seasonal pomegranate seeds or without. Order the Cochinita Pibil and experience what Mexican food is like without a ton of yellow cheese melted on top of it. Enjoy the gorgeous art on the walls inside and outside of the restaurant.

If I could give this place 10 stars I would. Few months ago I was in Phoenix for a conference and realized a feature triple d joint was around the corner from my hotel. I ended up at this location two times and the other location (barrio cafe Gran reserva) once. Mind you I was only in the area for four nights! I chose to eat at the bar both times- which was great- tiny but no one was there at same time as me so it worked . Bartenders both nights were very friendly . I ordered the same thing both times - cochinita pibil - and I continue to dream about it months later. I have never tasted anything as succulent and simple but with complex flavor profile - I take my hat off to Chef Silvana- please open a restaurant in NYC!

Great atmosphere, awesome murals outside.  I ordered the mango salad and it was very good and presented very beautifully.  My only complaint is that the food seemed expensive for the amount of food.  Overall, good experience!

Interesting Mexican. A different take on the standards. Very fresh.  Chips are a bit greasy and not to par in my opinion for this place.   Very good place and I recommend it but I don't see the "the best Mexican"  Great service.   I didn't have the drinks but I am sure they are excellent

This place is a little off the beaten track unless you live in the neighborhood, but it well worth seeking out. It's not far from the Phoenix Art Museum and the Heard, and makes a great stop before or after a trip to one of the museums if you're trying to think of a fun outing with visiting friends or family and want to impress and convince them to keep coming back. If you don't like your family that much, and don't want them to come too often, then don't take them here.  You can't go wrong with any dish, but the Cochinita Pibil is one of their specialties, and the guacamole with pomegranate seeds is a surprising treat. It's worth going just for that.

I knew when I moved to Phoenix I would experience some top-notch Mexican food,but Barrio exceeded all expectations. The guacamole is one of a kind and CANNOT be missed. I had the shrimp tacos and they were perfection!  The cabbage was crisp the shrimp was perfectly cooked and the sauce was magnificent. This is the place I will bring all of my out of town guests!

Yet another place that has a reputation for good food and long ass lines. Another $40 meal that left me unsatified and confused. I'm left with these questions on my mind during and after the meal. What are the other people eating and are we in the wrong place?   The food here does not live up to the lore painted on the colorful walls and menu. The bread and dip brought out while we ordered was stale and the dip was unmemorable. My wife insisted that we order the guacamole. I was not a fan of the flavor combinations of pomegranate and lime. It was Sunday, so we ordered from the brunch menu. I had the enchiladas verde and was extremely disappointed. The enchiladas were okay in certain places but mostly tasted like something I could cook at home myself. I absolutely hated everything else on the plate from the soupy and over sweetened verde sauce, burned potatoes and pico de gallo that was just out of place on the dish.   At least the place was not crowded. I would have had to ask for a refund if I waited 2 hours like I've heard people do. The live music was cool and the place had a nice atmosphere. The only thing missing was good food.

My favorite restaurant, period. I adore the esquites, quesadilla cameron, and the goats milk caramel churros... I would easily give it five stars, HOWEVER they frequently turn off the ringer on their phone so we can never call in and order takeout! When asked about it we were told by one of the owners that, "We do it on purpose, in house customers are more important - but we answer during lunch!" (WTH?!) Meanwhile, the phone rings on silent while the hostess ensures her Snapchat is updated every 30 seconds.  We are frequently in house customers as well, it would be really nice to enjoy our favorite dishes in house or from our couch. Sadly after the last interaction I'm not sure we will be such frequent guests.
Great environment, live guitar, delicious food, and excellent service!!!!  I would highly recommend checking Barrio Cafe out!!!

Had to come to this place because of all the great things I've heard. Should have looked into it a little more because it was definitely more pricey than I anticipated. This place is tiny so prepare to wait. However, service was good. My husband and I both ordered tortas and they were delicious!! When we can afford it, we'll be back to try something else.

Me and my wife ate there for the first time after viewing the show diners, drive ins and dives. The food was amazing took flavor to another level, drank a michelada while waiting excellent drinks. Worth the wait, good service as well.

This place is amazing.  One of my two favorite spots in AZ so far.    The lobster quesadilla is awesome.  not your typical quessadilla but way way better.  the flank steak torta was very good too.  i can't wait to go back and try everything else.

What a disappointment.  We started off with fresh, yet strange tasting guac.  They make it at your table - avocado, lime (not enough), onions, cilantro and dried cranberries.  Yes, dried cranberries.  Sound funny?  Well, let me tell you, it tastes just as funny as it sounds.  Its a very weird sensation to be eating guacamole with chips and chewing on cranberries.   I wanted it to work out, but it just didn't. I ordered the seafood enchiladas for my entree.  They were so banal that I didn't even go for dessert.  I do have to mention that I tried my husband's duck entree and it was pretty darn good.  But still, that means this place is batting .33 which is not a good record for a moderate-high priced Mexican restaurant.    Also, I would rate this a $$$ and not a $$.

I came here for lunch and lucky for me, it wasn't too busy. We were seated right away and my date and I ordered the Tacos Camaron (shrimp tacos) and the Torta Poblano. The waiter was slow and took forever to place our order, get refills, and give us our check. Pretty annoying...  However, the food was incredibly good. I practically ate more than I should of but, I could not stop eating. The shrimp was delightful and tasty, the torta poblano was just as good. Before tip, our bill was less than $30.   I am definitely a fan of the food. The service needs some improvement.

I was looking for a nice mexican restaurant to have a nice meal with my wife and found Barrio café online.  When we got there it seemed very small. As I entered I was told by a not so courteous girl (she seemed to be new and not very good with people) that it would be at least 45 min to and hour wait. As the place is small but interesting we decided to wait it out. Finally after 45 minutes they called us. We got seated to a small table with artsy chairs and table, the place is interesting because of the Mexican artsy objects. The waiter was very nice and the menu looked promising , everything in the menu was very pricy but we figured the meals would make up for the high prices. My wife ordered enchiladas suizas and i ordered enchiladas with black mole. When the meals arrived I immediately noticed there where no rice and beans , and I thought to myself seriously ?? Really ?? I asked the waiter if I could order 2 side orders of rice for our meals and he said "oh we don't have rice and beans.  I was stunned because normally all mexican restaurants serve rice and beans with the meals.  But we were so hungry that we accepted it because we have waited to long to eat. The food was good but it didn't satisfy my hunger , each plate was $22 and for that price I would have got a killer meal at and upscale Mexican restaurant with all the bells and whistles , so therefore we do not recommend  this place very pricey and not worth the wait. It's a cute place but not worth the money. After paying $67 I was still hungry

It's sad, but I really like my chips and salsa (complimentary or not) when I go out for Mexican food. Barrio has a buschetta-esque chips and salsa substitute that no one really liked.  I had a Sergio el Suave (tequila, pineapple, lime juice, candied jalapeno, etc) to start. It was actually a bit spicy and interesting.  We had the queso as an app, and most of us got tacos, which come with "spicy" fries or a salad. I tried both and liked both. Everyone polished off their fries.   The brunch menu looked like something worth coming back for.
Love this place. Great place to go after work! Great service and tasty food. The bar is well stocked and the staff are knowledgeable.

Outstanding food! Great service! Neat place! Live music! Nothing negative to say. We went on a Saturday around 6pm and I think that's just right on time before it get's crowded and you have to wait. The place it's small so big parties may have to be patient and wait. First thing we ordered was the Kuali de Camaron; amazing taste! A combinationof spicy and creamy and all things good, with tastefull chorizo and a perfectly marinated shrimp, the goat cheese just adds perfection to it, all on top of a crispy totopo.Your tastebuds will be very happy; just typig this makes my mouth watery!  You def have to try the tamarindo agua fresca. It's a must. Doesn't feel artificial at all and you can tell it's freshly made, you get the tamarindo pulp in it and the sweetness to it it's the right amount.  Our main entree, fish tacos and chicken suiza enchiladas. The tacos are a very good size and they are great option if you're not adventurous to try something different. They're def satisfying, though. The enchiladas: you get 5-6 enchiladas so it's a very generous portion. They have to be the best I've tried. Just look at the pictures. Oh, this place is not you average price, not a 10dll plate but it's totally worth it. Our check was about $65 for two.
If you're a foodie put this place on your list. Very creative culinary experience. Just won the award for best Mexican restaurant in US. Perhaps a bit generous. But a great experience.
Horrible attitude here! Unaccommodating when we had one extra person show up at our table.

(Have been back now three times since the original review.  This place is awesome.  I've had drinks, coffee, appetizers and a bunch of different entrees with my wife.  Everything is good.)  I went in to this place to hear a couple of my music buddies play near the beginning of 2010.  I knew nothing of the food or the place.  Because I was by myself, I got a table immediately which was not normal on a Saturday.  (There was a line out of the door at 8:30pm.)  I got to the third item on the menu as described below:  "C H I L E S  en  N O G A D A Roasted poblano pepper stuffed with chicken, onions,garlic, pecans, apples, pears and apricots finished with a delicate almond sacue and pomegranates $21"  I didn't read any further.  This is what I ate.  It was one of the most interesting and tasty entrees I have ever had in Phoenix.  I was thinking about it all week,  I tried to describe it to my wife but I couldn't.  The people who claim that the parking and neighborhood are less than ideal are not lying, but it's not that bad.   Honestly, I would risk having my car stolen to eat this food.  Heck, I might risk stealing your car to have this food.  Look, if you want safe, I'm sure you have a Chili's near your house that will gladly allow you to share your money with them.  I want to give the place 5 stars, but I think all I had was this one entree and probably water.   I remember liking the olive and bread that came before the meal, but my recollection is blurred by the Chiles en Nogada.  I really need to go back to verify if this will be a long term thing or a one-time fling.

I've been to Barrio twice now.  Simply put, I do not believe that it is worth the prices that they charge. The first time I went there was with the pseudo boyfriend and he adored his meal, and so I embraced it and loved it.  The second time was last night for Dottsy's birthday dinner.    Dottsy and I ordered up the guacamole that everyone raves about.  We were unimpressed, as we had huge chunks of avocado in there and have both made our own guacamole and didn't see what the big fuss was about.    I've had the enchiladas suizas and enchiladas de hongas and although they weren't bad- they were not amazing.  Not worth the 16 bucks, at all.  Don't get me wrong, I wouldn't complain about the cost if it tasted like it was worth it, but not so much.  Because it was Dottsy's birthday, they brought her a complimentary flan which we both agreed was pretty tasty flan.  So, if you are a flan person, this may be a place to check out.  I am not a flan person- too jiggly (which makes me think of what fat looks like on a person's body which stops me from eating it).  The two things that make this place worth going for are the margaritas and the service.  The margaritas are 50% tequila and fabulous- I usually just stick to the house margarita and am satisfied.  The people that work at Barrio are friendly and cool.  I imagine that they all enjoy working there.  I don't really ever need to go back to Barrio, unless I'm craving a serious margarita served up by a cute hipster.  I'd go for a drink or two and then go elsewhere for dinner.
Honest review. Good food. Too expensive. Let's not kid ourselves and try to up sell delicious Mexican food. Not a fan of the whole "upscale" Mexican food image. Too pricey.
Great place! Excellent service! Funky art! Not your typical Mexican restaurant! Love it!
Fly here, eat there. Do it! I had the Chile en Nogada and the first few bites were so emotional that I cried. I will be back, possibly tomorrow for lunch. So much more to try!

Don't expect typical tacos, enchiladas or burritos and the prices that go along with traditional food. Thus restaurant is what I would call modern Mexican.  My roasted pork plate  had a Mexican version of mashed potatoes with a side  of zucchini-$20. The dish was very good. No tortilla chips upon arrival ; they use French bread with a tapenade. Soup: corn chowder. We also had filet steak tacos-3 for $12 and came with salad. Chips and guacamole were very different. I liked them but probably wouldn't order again-$11.

A diamond in this rough neighborhood. Be prepared to wait, most nights it's very busy. Order one of their amazing margarita's and try to relax in their very limited space. I've tried a couple of things, but by far the best item is their seasonal Chiles en Nogada. Be sure to order their Guacamole, they make it right in front of you and add the fun twist of pomegranate seeds to the mix. It's awesome!

A very big disappoint extremely underwhelmed. Here is the problem with Chef inspired restaurants not everybody in the restaurant as inspired as the chef is. Very simple I ordered Rojas cheese enchiladas for $19 they brought me 3 street corn tortilla with enchilada sauce cilantro sprouts and the 2 eggs over easy that I did order. First thing I noticed sitting on top was the eggs were slightly undercooked this is bad... Can't cook an egg correctly. It was amazing the  corn tortillas had nothing inside I looked everywhere for the cheese even on the bottom of the plate no cheese they were literally corn tortillas with enchilada sauce. Now just think about that to roll up a corn tortilla and not notice anything inside meat or cheese was missing you would have to deliberately wilfully with disregard roll up the tortillas and place them on the plate. The wait staff was undetstaffed they don't have any quality control they serve the plate without even looking at it, really you pick up food you don't look at it before you serve it?... Jack N is correct Chef Esperaza has lost control of this restaurant first time here I will never come back. What a shame.. no way in hell can I possibly recommend this restaurant to anybody...another Triple D disaster.

Too much good stuff to choose just one.  Hands down the signature stuffed poblano is a must order.   Don't waste your time eating the  bread they bring to the table as you'll regret you wasted the stomach space .   Queso is just as menu reads and is an explosion of flavors.   Grab a bag of coffee too to take home.  A definite local spot I'd go back to.
Everything about this restaurant is amazing; the food, atmosphere, art, and staff. Not only is Chef Sylvana sharing her culture and food but she also contributes to the community in numerous ways.

What can be said that hasn't already - the fantastic guacamole (probably the best I've ever tasted), the addicted spicy fries and even-spicer ketchup, and the knock-your-socks-off-fan-freakin-tastic cochinita pibil. All incredible. I'd fly back to Phoenix just to eat here again. Til next time Barrio Cafe.

Does anyone else think it strange for a Mexican cafe to serve mediocre Bread instead of chips and salsa?   Service was very poor.  Carne asada tacos were flavorful    Probably won't come back here.  Too many other good choices close by

After seeing this place on triple D, I knew I had to add it to my bookmarks for when I visited Phoenix. Unfortunately for me, the food was just A-OK. This place seems to be very popular though as it was completely full with a line of people waiting at 6pm on a Thursday night.  Our server, Claudia, was really great and hooked it up with the chips for us. We are used to the typical free chips and salsa when going to a Mexican restaurant but this place gives bread and salsa.   I'm from Dallas, TX and here we have street tacos and street elotes in a cup for a little over $1 each. We started off with the Esquites which is pretty much like the street elotes we have at home but were pretty shocked a small bowl of it could cost $9. It was good, though. Just not $9 good. I guess I'm used to it being so cheap at home.  We tried the infamous chiles en nogada and were underwhelmed. There was a LOT going on in that dish and maybe it was too complex for our simpleton taste buds? I also could not believe it was a $24 dish...a tad overpriced in my opinion. Not sure what was in there that could make it $24.   I also had to try the acclaimed Cochinita Pibil and got it in taco form. Again, I was underwhelmed...I was excited for it since it is slow roasted over night. The pork was pretty mediocre and the texture wasn't as tender as I thought it would be.

I'm in utter disbelief of how bad this place was. With all of the amazing reviews I thought there was no way it could be bad. How on earth do they get such great reviews in AZ? There's so much better Mexican food here, even right down the street from Barrio. I will say the guacamole is great-super fresh but super awkward when your Henry Rollins look alike server is angrily smashing it together next to your table. Apparently he doesn't like that part of his job. Actually, it seemed like he pretty much hated his job, which may have ruined a lot of my experience. We ordered our guac & he asked if we wanted anything besides water-we told him we hadn't looked at the drink menu yet and he slams it back on the table and says "Guess I'll leave this here then"....sorry, Henry. I'm also the kind of person that says "thank you" throughout my meal...like when you fill my glass, bring my food, take my plate etc. Not once did he say "you're welcome". Such a douche. I did read in one other review that the servers treat you like you should be so lucky to be eating there. Definitely felt it. Anyway, got the Conchinita Pibil Tacos. Pork was dry and tortillas were soggy. You get 4 street tacos on corn tortillas and for some reason someone thinks its a good idea to dump salsa on them so they fall apart by the time they get to your table. Pair that with a side of Ore Ida steak fries and you have yourself a $13 dinner? Thank god I didn't spring for a pricier dish since I thought after the guacamole I'd be mostly full anyway. My boyfriend got the seafood Chile Relleno and said it was ok - for 21 bucks it should have been way better than ok - I don't eat seafood much so I didn't try it but I've seen him get more excited over a shrimp burrito from Señor Taco. To end the evening our server took 10 minutes to pick up our payment from our table, and blatantly ignored my boyfriend trying to get his attention. I took my leftovers in a to go box to be polite when the busser asked if I wanted them since I still had half a plate of food, but did not hesitate to throw them directly into the trash when I got home. I don't even normally write reviews, but I was so blown away by the vast difference between the reviews I'd read and my experience that I just had to. The only reason I'd ever return to this place would be for happy hour. Drinks and guacamole, yes. Dinner - never again.

I hate to be the "odd man out" here, but this place has done me wrong! I ended up just walking out without getting my food after 35 minutes!  Background: Abe has wanted to go to Barrio Cafe, he cooks and likes eating at hole in the wall places, all while supporting his community. He goes there twice on seperate occasions but both times they were closed. Today, as every Friday, Abe gets the urge to treat himself, he finds the Barrio Cafe after parking at Mercer Mortuary down the block since a sign told him he could.  11:40 Arrives at BC 11:41 Gets Seated immediately by what appears to be the owner, nice packed jeans" he thought. after responding to a salutation from what appears to be his partner  11:45 Notices there is hardly anyone in this joint however the couple across from me have a "I am here look" that Abe is used to since he has been a waiter in his past. No one seems to come to their aid.  11:48 a smartly dressed (in black) young man asks to get his drink to which Abe at the same time gives his order for the Taco Felitito (filet mignon steak taco)  11:55 Abe gets the side salad 12:00 Abe reads articles from his magazine 12:10 Abe continues reading more articles 5 all together all while wondering where his food is "medium rare steak takes 7 1/2 minutes to cook he thinks"  12:10 Abe sees other people coming into the place and filling this 30 seat cafe, he sees them getting their orders and eating all while drinking 3 glasses of Ice Tea 12:15 The waiter comes with no apology and says the "sandwich" will be ready in a few--Abe thinks "he didn't even get the order in till now" 12:20 dissatisfied Abe walks out, he drives back to his company where he works and orders 2 tacos from the company cafeteria instead.   Disclaimer: Although Abe does not mean to harm this establishment or to create negative repurcussions to his own community of gay-minded people, he is only expressing his experiences, this in no way reflects on gay people, and / or their ability to decorate and create meaningful pleasant enterprises.

I was in town on business and so I did the solo dinner out at Barrio Cafe.  Usually solo dinners go by quickly for me, since I'm usually just hungry, ready to go back to my hotel room after a long day on the road, and most importantly, nobody interesting to chat with over dinner.  I expected to spend 30 minutes there, tops.  Well, the food was so fantastic that I definitely lingered - probably about an hour.  Not exactly a world record for longest dinner, but a long time to be sitting at a table in a restaurant by yourself.  I didn't care since the cuisine was so good.  I started off with their signature guacamole - prepared tableside.  It was excellent and served with a basket of slightly greasy homemade tortilla chips.  The pomegranate seeds in the guac were a nice, unique addition.  I toyed around with several different potential selections for my entree, but at the waitress' recommendation settled on the stuffed pepper.  It was stuffed with chicken, fruits, nuts and a pleasant sauce.  I only wish there had been more of the stuffing.  It was fantastic.  I have to tell you I was thinking about ordering one of their tortas, but after making an offhand comment about good torta bread, the waitress advised me that it was served on a french roll.  The idea of a french roll taking the place of a soft, authentic torta bun turned me off, so I went with the stuffed pepper.  In retrospect, given the quality of the cuisine I ordered, I'm sure the torta would've been good - my preconceived notions of torta bread notwithstanding.  I finished off my meal with the churros.  Two homemade churros filled with creme caramel, drizzled with caramel, candied pecans,vanilla ice cream and raspberries - unbelievable.  The place was small and intimate.  Excellent food and a welcoming vibe, despite obviously being a place not frequently visited by out of towners.  Highly recommended.

Slipping.  We live in San Diego but get here at least once every two months.  Our last visit May 16 was not up to their standards.  Service was unprofessional with our waiter making stops asset other tables while holding our 'hot' food.  Furthermore they have reduced the portion size of their table side guacamole and our entrees just did not have the snap they used to...we will go back but will stick to their great happy hour and margaritas.

After seeing Barrio Cafe on Diners, Drive-Ins, and Dives we decided to check it out while we were in Phoenix for the day. We must have arrived right after the lunch rush hour, so we only had to wait about 10 minutes for a table. At this time on Saturday afternoon, there was happy hour so my husband went for 2 for 1 beers (Negro Modelo), while I went for the house-made horchata. It comes in a medio litro bottle and I almost finished the entire thing. Very good! For a starter we ordered the Queso Fundido, which had some loganiza chorizo in it which gave it a nice flavor. For our entrees we tried the Cochinita Pibil and Chiles en Nogada. I enjoyed my Chiles en Nogada becuase of the sweet and savory flavors, but it didn't blow me away as I thought it would. My husband's cochinita pibil was tender, but since he knows the secret to making pork like that he was also underwhelmed. While everything tasted good, we had higher expectations and thought that the prices were a bit expensive for what you get. That being said, I would go again to give some other items on the menu a try and see if I still feel the same way about the place.

I'm mainly posting this review to remind myself of the delicious Cochinita Pabil that I enjoyed here a few months ago while on vacation.  The margaritas, guacamole and dessert were solid too, but what I'll walk away remembering is that slow-roasted pork.  Delicious.

One of the best, upscale mexican food places in the city! Inventive and amazing flavors.  Went for lunch today and had the Cochinita pabil (sp?) torta and wife had the carne asada tacos with salad. Portions were generous and the service was good. If you want the same old same old, go to macayos for gringo sonoran food.

That this place is excellent is not news to the hundreds of you that are loyal to this place. Silvana is a force of nature, as you know.   Peg and I made our first trip to this place last week.  As is always the case with places that we love and visit again and again, there needs to be extraordinary everything. In this case, Marcos provided excellent service and the man (sadly, I do not know his name...yet)  who was taking care of busing tables, keeping beverages filled was incredible. In the midst of the whirlwind of activity, he was smiling and very efficient. The guacamole is legendary and will good reason. Pomegranate seeds in the midst of fresh ingredients and perfect avocados are genius.  The pollo poblano was a wonderful starter. The complementary dishes were tacos.....one featuring succulent pulled pork and the other, halibut..and they were simply amazing. When a familiar face is present, it makes the experience even more special. Julio Mata is one of the more accomplished chefs around and his skills elevate the whole playing field. We are delighted to include this place as one of our best ever places to relax and enjoy!  Dr. B

So I guess if all you have as comparison is other Phoenix restaurants, then this place deserves 3 stars.  However, if you have ever lived in California or traveled in Mexico, this place is over priced and over rated.  Sorry if I offended any fan but you need to try more upscale restaurants outside Arizona.

I want to love this place, I do, but every time we are here (because visitors insist on going) the food is mediocre and the servers are so pretentious.
